PARIS, Oct. 14--The French Government's reserves of gold and foreign exchange dropped by the equivalent of $500,000,000 between January and October, according to financial experts. The Liberal party announced yesterday its support of two state bond issues to be voted upon in the Nov. 6 election. One would provide $100,000,000 for loans for middle-income housing. The second would give $500,000,000 for highways.
The rapid ferment which has been altering the political fade of Eastern Europe in recent months continues. For the moment Hungary has the spotlight.

The leading article in the Political Science Quarterly is a contribution by Miroslav A. Kritz, Chief of the Foreign Research Division of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and is titled "The Tasks of Economic Statesmanship in the World of Today."
The first issue of the Sovietpublished magazine USSR to be cleared for sale in this country will appear on newsstands here on Oct. 23.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 14 --An eleven-year-old movie, presented for the first time on television Friday night at 8 o'clock in Los Angeles, appears to have scored decisively in an experiment being watched closely for implications of national significance by both the television and motion-picture industry.
MADRID, Oct. 14 (AP)--The new Spanish style of throwing the javelin like a discus probably will be outlawed in international competition because of danger to spectators.
State agencies announced plans yesterday for new assaults on two kinds of job discrimination. One attack will be concerned with racial bias, the other with prejudice against older workers.

LONDON, Oct. 14 (AP)--Group Capt. Peter Townsend, who a year ago was Princess Margaret's No. 1 suitor, ends his career in the Royal Air Force tomorrow. An Air Ministry spokesman said Captain Townsend's "wish" for retirement had been granted.

Activity in the foreign exchange market during the past week was limited. This was due in part to the abbreviated week when banks were closed on Friday in observance of Columbus Day. British pound sterling and Canadian dollar continued to maintain a steady undertone.

Staging a strong second-half attack to get both of its goals, the Maccabi Soccer Club of Tel Aviv, Israel, completed its tour of this country by beating the national team of Iceland, 2--0, at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.
Supervision of the eight centers of the Children's Aid Society will be the responsibility of John H. Dreasen, it was announced yesterday by Arthur Huck, executive director.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 14-- The Governor of Sao Paulo State has decided that the Brazilian Federal Government's censorship of radio and television is unconstitutional. He said he would not permit its implementation.
LONDON, Oct. 14 (AP)-- Premier Chou En-lai declared tonight that Communist China could not permit further Hong King disorders on the doorstep of China.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (UP)-- Goalie Ed Chadwick sparked the Toronto Maple Leafs to their first victory of the National Hockey League season tonight, a 1-0 decision over the Chicago Black Hawks. The Hawks suffered their second straight shutout.
At Emil Mogul Company, Inc., Miss Dorothy Kent, formerly with Grey Advertising Agency, named copy group head for cosmetics, toiletries and fashion...

With the telecasting of "Date With a Stranger" on the American Broadcasting Company network Oct. 30, "Du Pont Cavalcade Theatre" will drop the Cavalcade from its title. The story will dramatize the plight of an Austrian girl being deported from this country.
Nancy Kelly will receive the fourth annual award of the Sarah Siddons Society tonight in Chicago. She was selected for her performance there last season in "The Bad Seed."

Preferred Pictures Corp. motion picture sales, in 11 W 42d St; Travelands, Inc, travel agency, in 598 Madison Ave; Mr. Edd, Inc, men's sportswear, in 180 Madison Ave through Vought, Ward Nicholls, Inc; Claude J. Teyssier, aviation, in 500 5th Ave. --Cushman Wakefield, brokers.

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Oct. 14 (AP)--Pope Pius described woman today as creation's masterpiece. He said her "sublime mission" was maternity and deplored the fact that in some countries women worked in heavy industry.
Election of Richard S. Robie of Boston as a director of the Hertz Corporation was announced over the week-end by Walter L. Jacobs, president.
ROME, Oct. 14--The Italian Communist party professed today its determination to seek a democratic Italian way toward socialism.
TRENT, Italy, Oct. 14--The Christian Democratic party, which has dominated Italian politics and formed the backbone of all governments since World War II, is holding its biennial party congress here.

BREMERHAVEN, Germany, Oct. 14 (UP)--More than 2,000 German and Iron Curtain emigrants left here this week-end for new homes in the United States and Australia. The United States military transport General Taylor sailed with 1,175 Germans and escapees from Communist East Europe.
Five journalists will be honored Friday by Columbia University for their efforts toward the "advancement of international friendship in the Americas."

PARIS, Oct. 14 (UP)--A team of Soviet economic experts arrived here tonight to negotiate a two-year commercial treaty with France. The talks are an outgrowth of Premier Guy Mollet's visit to Moscow last May.

The Shinnihon Steamship Company will start a new direct freight service from Japan to United States ports on the Gulf of Mexico with the sailing of the Nachiharu Maru from Kobe Oct. 31. The service will augment the company's present runs to East Coast ports.
BOSTON, Oct. 14--In a New York Times dispatch from Boston, appearing in editions of Oct. 13, Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the Boston and Maine ...
VIENNA, Oct. 14 (UP)--Hungary defeated Austria, 2--0, in a soccer match before 60,000 spectators at Prater Stadium today. The Hungarians led, 1--0, at half-time.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Oct. 14 (AP)--A gas-turbine United States ship completed today what one expert described as a vibrationless journey across the Atlantic.
Gone are the days of the wagon jobbers--almost. At least one still thrives in the New York area: Henry Pape, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14--Dr. Jacob Kaplan, Grand Rabbi of Paris, was the guest of honor today of B'nai B'rith, Jewish service organization, which is celebrating its 113th anniversary.
DETROIT, Oct. 14 (UP)--Billy Dea, a rookie who was traded by the Rangers a year ago, scored the winning goal tonight as the Detroit Red Wings halted New York, 2--1, before 10,781 fans.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 14 (UP) --The Cincinnati Redlegs today purchased a right-handed pitcher, Elmer Singleton, from Seattle of the Pacific Coast League and an outfielder, Ultus (Chico) Alvarez, from Havana of the International League.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14--Lard trade here has been of moderate volume with modest price swings. The general undertone has been firm, influenced by a better tone in vegetable oils and forecasts of a substantial volume of export business.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 13-- A searing sun and the worst drought in fifty years have burned up a lot of Eisenhower votes as well as crops in Oklahoma.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP)-- Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, said today that a "cloak of secrecy" had been used by the Eisenhower Administration to try to cover up "a variety of charges of improper actions" in the postal service.
Roman Catholics attended an outdoor rally at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon to honor Pope Pius XII as their spiritual leader and champion of world peace.

Miss Judith Ann Shill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Eli Shill of Flushing, Queens, was married there yesterday afternoon to Ronald Charles Ablow, son of Mrs. Benjamin Ablow of Salem, Mass., and the late Mr. Ablow. The ceremony was performed in the Free Synagogue of Flushing by Rabbi Max Meyer.

Mrs. Roslyn Oshinsky Golding, daughter of Mrs. Philip Feinberg of New York and the late Israel M. Oshinsky, was married yesterday to Jack Nass, also of this city. The bridegroom is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Max Nass. The ceremony was performed in the Plaza by the Rev. Dr. Louis C. Gerstein.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14--A point that the Democrats are planning to press in the days before the election is that the consumer installment debt is at a record high of almost $30,000,000,000.
LONDON, Monday, Oct. 15 (Reuters)--The News Chronicle announced today that newspapers from six nations in Western Europe had formed an association to promote European unity.

Budd Roth, retired director of the Foreign Trades Bureau and a public relations specialist in the early days of radio and aviation, died Friday night in the Adelph Hospital, Brooklyn. His age was 54.
The biggest coordinated effort to find out motorists' traffic habits in the metropolitan area will get under way this week.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Oct. 14--The La Salle Military Academy football team scored its third victory in four starts by crushing St. Agnes High, 32--0, today. It was the first triumph for the cadets, in the Nassau-Suffolk Catholic High School League.
NEWARK, Oct. 14--Gov. George M. Leader of Pennsylvania denied today that he had suggested Alcatraz Island as a retirement place for Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, will address the sixty-first annual Congress of American Industry ...
Miss Barbara Carole Schlanger and Charles Lee Greenebaum were married here last evening in the ballroom of the Pierre. The Rev. Alvin Schraeder performed the ceremony.
The First District Dental Society here will present its Henry Spenadel Award to Dr. Herbert Kurtz Cooper, dentist of Lancaster, Pa., a pioneer in cleftpalate treatment.

Mrs. Mary Fanton Roberts, a former newspaper woman and magazine editor who helped to sponsor the American debuts of many, leading artistic figures of her day, died yesterday at the New York Infirmary.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 14 (Reuters)--Floods threatening New Delhi today drowned thirtyfour persons in a village eighteen miles from the capital. Outside the old city of Delhi flood waters of the River Jumna were thirty inches abouve the danger mark, threatening the city with the worst flood in its history.

TRENTON, Oct. 14--The marriage of Miss Lynne Blaugrund, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Blaugrund, to Dr. Alvin H. Felman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Felman of Cincinnati, took place here today. The ceremony was performed in the Hildebrecht Hotel by Rabbi Joshua O. Haberman.
"Religion is a living thing to be created within each individual, not an entity to be put into the life of a child," the Rev. Dr. Frederick May Eliot said yesterday.

Following is the unofficial summary, by Assembly Districts, of the final registration in New York City for the 1956 election. Because new district lines were established in 1954 no accurate comparison by Assembly Districts can be made with previous Presidential yesars. The recapitualtion shows the comparison, by boroughs, with 1954, a state-wide year, and 1952, a Presidential year.

Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey, returning yesterday from a campaign trip to California, predicted that Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic Presidential candidate, would win the West Coast state in a close election.
Stuart Herman, realty operator, has bought the fifty-twofamily apartment house on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 2530 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, from J. Grossinger through Alexander Herman, broker.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 13--A silvery aircraft--The Kefauver Mainstreeter--taxis to a stop. A wheeled stairway is rolled up. The plane door opens. A highschool band or, more frequently, a sound truck blares "The Tennessee Waltz." And Senator Estes Kefauver, Democratic candidate for Vice President, winces.
A decline from the record Presidential vote cast four years ago in New York State appeared certain yesterday on the basis of last week's personal registration results.

The steamship charter market last week held firm on rates. The weekly survey of the market found rates on some commodities off slightly, but such losses were balanced by gains in other cargoes. Tanker activity continued "dullish" and rates clung to the levels of the past month.

IT'S still a dramatic way to conduct Sunday vesper serv ices. But Christopher Fry's "Thor, With Angels," receiving its first New York presentation by the Broadway Chapel Players, is sometimes a strain on both the ears and the intellect.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 14--Alex Webster scored three touchdowns as the New York Football Giants upset the champion Cleveland Browns, 21-9, before 60,042 spectators at Municipal Stadium today.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 14--The National Liberation party of President Jose Figueres appears on the verge of being split during the President's absence from the country.

Tomorrow morning the Seeing Eye, Inc., will open its campaign for support. Its permanent home is in New Jersey, but the appeal for help from the public will start here in New York at the Academy of Science. The scope of the organization is, of course, nation-wide.

LONDON, Oct. 14--The Financial Times index of thirty industrial ordinary shares, based on July, 1935, as 100, at the end of last week was 176.1, compared with 178.8 the week before, 181.2 a month earlier and 188.2 a year ago.
President Eisenhower and Adlai E. Stevenson, his Democratic opponent, yesterday ruled out bigotry and intolerance in the election campaign.
Servomechanisms, Inc., has announced the opening of new corporate offices at 445 Park Avenue, at East Fifty-seventh Street.
The current college football season has brought forth its full quota of surprises but none of them has been quite so staggering as the fate that befell Army at Ann Arbor Saturday.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 14 (UP)--Jack Regas piloted Hawaii Kai III at an average speed of 98.6842 miles per hour today to win the Sahara Cup hydroplane race on Lake Mead.
Mayor Wagner last night advocated a $500,000,000 annual Federal aid program for colleges and universities in the next ten years to meet a "national crisis in higher education."

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 14-- The head of the World Zionist Organization and other Zionist leaders stressed tonight that a permanent peace in the Middle East would convert that area into "one of the greatest civilizations of all time."

Colgate-Palmolive Company has named Norman, Craig Kummel, Inc., to handle advertising for its Veto deodorant. New at Philip J. Perlman Associates: Bencone Uniforms, Inc., mail-order house; Canterbury Belts, Ltd., men's belts, and R.B. Philips Company, Inc., house furnishings.
Former Gov. Walter E. Edge of New Jersey was reported in fair condition yesterday after his second operation within five months.

MYSORE, India, Oct. 14.--In the courtyard of his palace, a royally portly Maharaja with diamonds in his ears bowed today before the jeweled sword of his ancestors and prayed. In a side-street stall, a tailor put garlands on his sewing machine and prayed. In his tiny worship room at home, a school teacher sprinkled his books with petals and prayed.
Robert B. Meyner, the Democratic Governor of New Jersey, said yesterday there was "growing support" for Adlai E. Stevenson in his state.
OTTAWA, Oct. 14--Canada is going through one of her regular periods of concern about her world trade situation.
Directors of the Hammond Organ Company have declared an extra dividend of 25 cents a share in addition to the regular quarterly payment of 35 cents a share on the common stock.

Two off-Broadway openings are on tonight's calendar. They are "Me, Candido!" at the Greenwich News Theatre, 141 West Thirteenth Street, and a program of three short Pirandello plays at The Open Stage, 15 Second Avenue. The former will start at 8 P.M. and the latter at 7:45 P.M.
City and state officials and members of the bench and bar attended in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday the Votive Mass of the Holy Spirit, known from its vestments as the "Red Mass."

CAIRO, Oct. 14 (AP)--The police said tonight an average of eighty-seven merchants have been arrested weekly since the start of the Suez crisis, July 26.

Custom smelters trimmed their price for copper 2 cents a pound yesterday, to 37 cents. The anticipated fall pick-up in demand had failed to meet expectations and prices abroad continued to weaken.

Two business executives won awards for distinguished service to higher education last night. They also received congratulations from President Eisenhower.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Oct. 18 (AP)--New Britain High School students in a mock election today gave President Eisenhower 800 votes and his democratic opponent, Adlai E. Stevenson, 588. Four years ago they favored Stevenson 787 to 583. New Britain is a heavily industrialized city.
In May, 1944, United States Navy task group 22.3, known as a "hunter-killer" group, sailed from Norfolk, Va., to look for submarines.
State Commerce Commissioner Edward T. Dickinson disclosed yesterday that he will seek a $600,000 advertising budget to promote industrial development and tourist business.
Member banks across the country improved their net reserve position $348,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
The Bates Manufacturing Company has agreed to buy the Consolidated Textile Company's 1,800-loom cotton print cloth mill at Lynchburg, Va., for $1,250,000.
For nations concerned with the free movement of water-borne commerce Egyptian President Nasser's seizure and control of the Suez Canal have produced a critical problem.

A commitment of $796,800 has been made by the Federal Housing Administration for the construction of sixty-two cooperative housing units for middleincome families and elderly persons in Woodside, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18--Senator Albert Gore challenged today the Eisenhower Administration's "policy of heedless testing of bigger and ever bigger hydrogen weapons."
FRANKFORT, Ky., Oct. 18 (UP)--Senator Harry F. Byrd said today that he had not authorized the use of his name on the Kentucky ballot as the States Rights party's candidate for President.

LONDON, Oct. 18--Sir Walter Monckton, 65 years old, resigned tonight as Minister of Defense. Antony Head, 50, who has been Secretary for War since the Conservative Government took office in 1951, was named to succeed him.
Thirty representatives of bloodbank associations in New York State met yesterday in the Einhorn Auditorium of Lenox Hill Hospital.
Ben Agajanian, a 38-yearold place-kicking specialist, agreed yesterday to return to the New York Football Giants.
Governor Harriman said yesterday that he had protested against the campaign appearance at Cornell University of Vice President Richard M. Nixon on Wednesday.
The United States oil industry will spend more than $5,000,000,000 this year to expand and improve its facilities to meet the increased demand for petroleum products.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 18--Yale University reported today a surplus for the twelve months ended June 30, 1956. This was the first time in five years that the university had ended its fiscal year with a surplus.

MANCHESTER, England, Oct. 18 (Reuters)--The Manchester Guardian endorsed today the appeal for an end to hydrogen bomb tests made by Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic Presidential candidate in the United States. "Mr. Stevenson has raised a moral issue," the Guardian said.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UP) --The Federal Trade Commission today charged the Vendo Company of Kansas City, Mo., the nation's largest manufacturer of soft drink vending machines, with illegally acquiring a major competitor, the Vendorlator Manufacturing Company of Fresno, Calif.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 18 (UP)-- Art Hunter, a former tackle at Notre Dame, unexpectedly joined the Cleveland Browns of the National Football League today. Hunter had been serving with the Army in the Far East and Coach Paul Brown had not been counting on him until next year.
WARSAW, Oct. 18--The bright sun, the autumn gold of the trees and the inviting snap of October weather cloaked Warsaw in a false display of serenity today.
A sum estimated at $26,000 was raised last night for the Will Rogers Memorial Hospital at Saranac Lake, N.Y., in a benefit showing of "Around the World in 80 Days" at the Rivoli Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)-- The Government today charged three of the countrys' biggest dairy corporations with violating the monopoly laws by acquiring a combined total of 251 dairy companies since 1951.
Oklahoma, beware! This has been a banner season for snapping streaks, points out Steve Boda of the National Collegiate Athletic Bureau.
The following food items are recommended as good buys by the Department of Markets:
THE dark-wood carved round table that stood in the skip per's cabin in the old frigate Constitution during her engagements with His Majesty's ships of the line, the Guerriere ...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)-- One section has been completed in the United States portion of the St. Lawrence Seaway, which is due to be fully ready for navigation by 1959.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UP) --The Agriculture Department spent $6,400,000 for hamburger, frozen turkeys, eggs and lard today in an effort to bolster farm prices.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18-- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Saturday, totaled 823,207 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

DETROIT, Oct. 18 (AP)--The Greater Detroit, the world's largest sidewheeler and long a Great Lakes pleasure cruiser, is to be disposed of as scrap. The same fate befell her sister ships, the City of Cleveland III and the Eastern States, owned by the Detroit and Cleveland Navigation Company.
A jury in Surrogate's Court last night was unable to agree if the maker of a will disposing of a $400,000 estate was mentally competent when she signed the document.
JOPLIN, Mo., Oct. 18--Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee said today that he "must have" set a handshaking record last night.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 18 (UP)--Mrs. Eleanor Ruotolo, whose infant daughter was kidnapped and murdered, left Midlletown State Hospital today.
Clarence H. Baumhefner has been named vice president and cashier of the Bank of America, of San Fancisco, S. Clark Beise, president, announced yesterday.
The Women's Volunteer Service Corps will hold its annual bazaar at St. Barnabas Hospital, 183d Street and Third Avenue, the Bronx, tomorrow.
The opening of a three-day drive for the $3,500,000 United Hospital Fund Campaign was deferred from yesterday to today, because of unfavorable weather.
Following is the text of an address by Vice President Richard M. Nixon last night at the twelfth annual Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation Dinner:

TORONTO, Oct. 18 (Canadian Press)--Imperial Oil, Ltd., said today it had filed with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 1,504,271 additional shares to be offered to shareholders on the basis of one new share for every twenty shares held.

DETROIT, Oct. 18 (AP)--Union shipyard workers today condemned the Eisenhower Administration for what they called the surrendering of the national wealth and the functions of government "to a select group of multi-millionaires."
GARY, Ind., Oct. 18 (AP)-- Former President Harry S. Truman charged tonight that President Eisenhower had allowed the Soviet Union to get a foothold in the eastern Mediterranean.
TRENT, Italy, Oct. 18 (UP)-- A younger generation took over the helm of Italy's largest noncommunist party tonight. It pledged far-reaching social reforms and continued friendship with the West.

CHANUTE, Kan., Oct. 18 (AP) --Senator William F. Knowland of California said today Adlai E. Stevenson "is treading on dangerously thin ice" in calling "for an agreement with the U.S.S.R. on termination of testing of nuclear weapons."
U. ALEXIS JOHNSON, who met yesterday for the sixtieth time with a Chinese Communist official to discuss the release of Americans from prisons in Red China, is a patient man.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18--An investigating panel of the House of Representatives was told today that President Eisenhower had agreed early in his Administration to the schooling of department and agency heads in "the political facts of life" on the awarding of Government contracts.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18 (UP)--The United States Court of Appeals denied today Caryl Chessman's eleventh attempt in eight years to escape the San Quentin gas chamber.

A medical leader predicted yesterday that hospital social workers might well move out of the charity wards and into the field of private and semi-private medical care. This, he said, might result from this nation's vast programs of prepaid medical care.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 18 (UP)-- Voter registration in Chemung County reached a record of 50,440, it was announced today. Figures from eleven towns showed an increase of 2,272 for a total of 27,792. Registration in Elmira decreased 1,778 for a total of 22,648. The previous record was 49,946 in 1952. The figures do not include service men.
The Association of American Railroads today reported installations of 1,125 new locomotive units in the first nine months of this year, compared with 786 in the same period in 1955.
The next few years will see the development of many chemicals capable of changing the quality of human consciousness, Aldous Huxley predicted here last night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)-- The United States Court of Appeals upheld today a deportation order against Henrik Mannerfrid, president of a New York corporation engaged in the export-import business.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 18 (AP)--John M. Haid Jr., 20 years old, of Siloam Springs, Ark., was elected today as national president of the Future Farmers of America. He was named at the closing session of the annual convention to succeed Daniel B. Dunham of Lakeview, Ore.
SEVEN very well-known twentieth-century French painters are represented in the current exhibition at Paul Rosenberg's.
Nine engines with ratings from 113 to 232 horsepower are available on the 1957 Dodge truck line announced yesterday by the Chrysler Corporation.

DETROIT, Oct. 18 (AP)--The Detroit Tigers today signed a full working agreement with Erie of the Class D Pony League. The Tigers for nine years had a working agreement with Jamestown, but that Pony League club folded at the end of the 1955 season.

Building and permanent loan mortgages totaling $1,164,000 have been arranged by M.L. Spies Associates, mortgage brokers of Jamaica, L.I., for Rainbow Village, Inc., a project of ninety-seven houses on Carrol Street and Washington Avenue in Brentwood, L.I.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)-- Horace B. McCoy, a veteran of thirty-six years in Federal service, was sworn in today as head of the Commerce Department's Business and Defense Services Administration.

PARIS, Oct. 18 (AP)--Gen. Sir Gordon Nevil Macready, a former assistant chief of the British Imperial General Staff and one-time head of the British Army Staff in Washington, died in Paris yesterday. He was 65 years old.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)-- The Public Health Service said today it was helping to develop effective prepaid dental-care programs.
Joe Jones carried the colors of Mrs. Ethel Jacobs to victory in the Sport Page Handicap yesterday at Jamaica, where the racing scene shifted from Belmont for the final meeting of the local season.
A two-day visit by Adlai E. Stevenson will bring the Democratic campaign in New York toward a crescendo in the week ahead.

BURBANK, Calif., Oct. 18 (AP) --A union leader assailed today as "pure politics" a plan of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation to allow 25,000 workers to hear President Eisenhower speak on his arrival tomorrow.

ABERDEEN, Md., Oct. 17 (AP) Two of the late Hermann Goering's automobiles, including, a convertible with a bullet-resistant top, will be sold at an Army auction Oct. 25. The Germanmade Mercedes Benz cars were used by the Nazi leader during the war.
The appointment of Mrs. Ruth B. Traynor to the newly created post of Director of Law Placement at the Columbia University School of Law was announced yesterday by Dean William C. Warren.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., Oct. 18-- A son was born to Lieut. (j.g.) Robert C. Angus, U.S.N.R., and Mrs. Angus in the Naval Hospital here on Oct. 11. Mrs. Angus is the former Miss Jane Calvert Cooper, daughter of Rear Admiral Thomas F. Cooper, Medical Corps, U.S.N., and Mrs. Cooper of Bethesda, Md. The child will be named Robert Cooper.
MUNICH, Germany, Oct. 18 (Reuters)--The governing body of the International Chamber of Commerce today began a twoday closed meeting here to discuss a wide range of commercial problems.

THE Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra is New York's own. When it begins its season, you know that concert time is here in earnest. It was an occasion, then, when the orchestra launched its 115th season at Carnegie Hall last night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UP) --The Army announced today the development of a one-shot flame thrower that can be carried into combat by parachute troops.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Oct. 18-- The Grange of Shiloh, N.J., voted unanimously last night to bestow a life membership upon Granger Eber M.R. Davis, who received the honor in absentia. Mr. Davis is 99 years old.

The Standard Pressed Steel Company announced yesterday that common stockholders would receive rights to subscribe for 25,800 additional common shares at the rate of one new share for every twenty held on last Tuesday.

PARIS, Oct. 18 (Reuters)-- Tony Revillon, 65-year-old former Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, was elected today president of the new Radical Socialist party. This is the group that broke away from the Radical party of former Premier Pierre Mendes-France.

"Two Loves Had I," an Italianmade romantic drama in Technicolor based on the life of Giacomo Puccini, has been acquired for release in this country from Rizzoli Film of Italy by Jacon Film Distributors, Inc.
ANY conscientious reader of contemporary American fiction knows moments when he feels that Mississippi must be far and away the most interesting state south of Mason and Dixon's line.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 18 (UP)--Gov. James E. Folsom, a supporter of Adlai E. Stevenson's proposal to halt tests of the hydrogen bomb, said today ...
BALTIMORE, Oct. 18 (UP)-- George M. Humphrey said today President Eisenhower had demonstrated that the nation did not need "the stimulant of war to rise to high levels."

Miss Madeline Russo has been named manager of Franklin Simon's new store in Manhasset, L.I., according to an announcement by Gordon K. Greenfield, president of Franklin Simon and City Specialty Stores, Inc.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 18 (AP)--Mayor Donald H. Mead, a Republican, was perplexed today how to interpret a letter from Senator Estes Kefauver, the Democratic candidate for Vice President. The letter said:
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 18 --Dane Clark, one of the three continuing stars of "Wire Service" will step out of his character role as a reporter for a few days.
ALBANY, Oct, 18 (AP)--A bus service "slowdown" here went into its third day today, but more persons got to work and school on time by making an early start.

A daughter, their third child, was born here to Mr. and Mrs. Basil B. Elmer Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., on Oct. 10 at LeRoy Hospital. Mrs. Elmer is the former Miss Isabel Lincoln, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic W. Lincoln of 280 Park Avenue and Greenwich.
A shake-up of top executive personnel of Loew's, Inc., occurred yesterday, two weeks after the sudden resignation of Arthur M. Loew as president of the company.

TOKYO, Oct. 18 (UP)--Thousands of flag-waving baseball fans lined the twelve-mile route from Haneda Airport to downtown Tokyo despite a drizzle tonight and accorded a rousing welcome to the Brooklyn Dodgers.
Thirteen contracts totaling $515,535 have been awarded to private shipyards on the East Coast by the Atlantic area command of the Military Sea Transportation Service.
Fencing as a varsity sport has been dropped by Fordham University as an economy measure. This was revealed yesterday by the Rev. Victor Yanitelli, faculty moderator of athletics.
Seven persons were injured last night in a two-alarm fire in a restaurant at 123 Second Avenue, near Seventh Street.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., Oct. 18 (AP)--Air Force golfers from twenty-two states representing the seven divisions of the Eastern Air Defense Force finished their fifty-four-hole medalist play today and T/Sgt. John Ford of Travelers Rest, S.C., won with 227.

The most significant single fact about Wednesday's dock union representation election is not that the old International Longshoremen's Association won, but that there remains on the waterfront a hard core of resistance to that union's policies and leadership.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 18 (AP)-- The Maryland Racing Commission today turned down a proposal for quinella betting on horses at the Laurel meeting starting next Wednesday.
TEL AVIV, ISRAEL, Oct. 18 (AP)--An American woman sentenced to a year in prison as a spy for Syria will appeal to Israeli authorities for a pardon, her defense counsel said today.
The Blair Holdings Corporation has completed a plan for disposing of its ownership of Blair Co., Inc., to the present management of the investment banking subsidiary.
Robert Moses suggested yesterday that the building of five commercial theatres north of Columbus Circle might force a modernization of the older playhouses in the Times Square area.
This is today's campaign schedule for the major Presidential and Vice-Presidential candidates, according to The Associated Press.

HUNTERS this year are facing again the growing problem of posted land. Maybe it would be more accurate to say that they are not facing it but, except in the case of some organized groups, just growling about it.

TAIPEI, Oct. 18 (AP)--Nationalist China's request that Red China be barred from the Olympic Games Nov. 22-Dec. 8 will be discussed by the International Olympic Committee in Melbourne Nov. 19, according to the Chinese (Nationalist) Olympic Committee.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 (AP) --The National Football League is going back to the old-fashioned style of having quarterbacks either think for themselves or receive instructions by messengers on foot.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Oct. 18 (AP)--The first two weeks of March have been picked for the 1960 Winter Olympic Games at Squaw Valley to avoid California storms.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 18 (AP)--A son was born yesterday to Ben Alexander, actor, and his wife Lesley at Hollywood Presbyterian Hospital. The child was the couple's second. His father plays a police officer on the "Dragnet" radio and television programs.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 18--Vice President Richard M. Nixon produced today what may prove to be the one and only understatement of the Presidential campaign.
Stocks reversed their recent pattern yesterday. They opened mixed and a little soft, marked time in the morning and made a sustained rise in the afternoon.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18-- Lack of cooperation between the Federal Home Bank Board and state banking authorities weakens the dual banking system, John G. Forrest, financial and business editor of The New York Times, said today.
Bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States rose seasonally by $32,642,000 to $805,114,000 in September, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

The Dec. 11 performance of "The Happiest Millionaire," starring Walter Pidgeon, will benefit the Brantwood Camp in Peterborough, N.H. The camp is operated by St. Mark's School, Southboro, Mass., for underprivileged New York and Boston boys.

MONTREAL, Oct. 18 (UP)-- Glen Skov's third-period goal enabled the Chicago Black Hawks to gain a 1-1 tie with the Montreal Canadiens tonight. This was Chicago's first point of the infant National Hockey League season.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Oct. 18 (AP) --French authorities reported today the slaying of a Roman Catholic nun, Sister Marie of the White Sisters Order. She had been kidnaped by nationalist rebels, along with Sister Dorothy.

SPARTANBURG, S.C., Oct. 18 (AP)--Julius Boros of Mid Pines, N.C., fired his third straight sub-par round today to win the Carolinas Professional Golfers Association tournament with a 209 for fifty-four holes.

A Federal court jury received yesterday the case against Acy Lennon, a secretary to Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. After more than ten hours of deliberation the jurors were locked up for the night at 12:55 A.M. today. Lennon is charged with evading income taxes from 1949 to 1954.
MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 18--Despite forty years of radical economic and social changes in the area comprising the Second Congressional District, it has remained Republican.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold warned today that Israel was jeopardizing the Palestine armistice by deciding that she could deal with border violations without United Nations supervision. Israel is boycotting the United Nations truce machinery.

PARIS, Oct. 18--The foreign ministers of six European nations will try to remove important obstacles to a European union at a meeting here Saturday. They will represent France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 18 (Reuters)--Jazz-loving King Phumiphon Aduldet, 28year-old monarch of Thailand, announced today his intention to enter the Buddhist priesthood for fifteen days, beginning Monday.

The United States and Foreign Securities Corporation reported yesterday net assets of $125,817,175, equals to $38 a share, as of Sept. 30. This compares with net assets of $128,950,171, or $38.95 a share, on Dec. 31, 1955.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18--Experts from sixteen countries will meet here on Monday to begin their study of the effects on human beings of the radioactive fall-out from nuclear-bomb explosions.
TOKYO, Oct. 18 (AP)--Jory, a Schnauzer who hates cages and distrusts strangers, finally got to Tokyo today after having been missing for two weeks in Alaska. His mistress had to fly back to get him.
RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 18-- A special committee nominated William C. Friday today to be the next President of the Consolidated University of North Carolina.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Oct. 18--Adlai E. Stevenson suggested tonight that the draft might be replaced by a professional, specially trained, highly paid volunteer defense corps. Mr. Stevenson presented his proposal as one for national consideration.

TOKYO, Oct. 18 (AP)--The United States paroled four more Japanese war criminals today. This reduced the number of war criminals still serving sentences at Tokyo's Sugamo Prison to 149, of which ninety-eight were sentenced by the United States, forty-seven by Australia, and four by Britain.
SEATTLE, Oct. 13--A-frustrated voter in work shirt and jeans tore out of a polling booth here a month ago and shouted at the election judges, "Where am I supposed to mark my ballot against this 198?"
The price of raw linseed oil was raised yesterday for the second time this week by leading flaxseed crushers.
The outlook for a successful termination of the New York City Opera Company's season appeared much more hopeful yesterday.
Lawrence D. Bell, chairman of the Bell Aircraft Corporation, last month reduced his investment in that company's securities to 2,000 shares of common stock from 32,000.

The Red Cross will collect blood today from the community of Queens Village at the Roman Catholic Church of the Incarnation, 207th Street and Eightyninth Avenue, Queens. Personnel of the United States Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn will also give blood.

OTTAWA, Oct. 18 (Canadian Press)--The Israeli Government has signed a contract with Canadair, Ltd. of Montreal for the purchase of twenty-four Sabre jet fighter planes, it was learned today. The total price is around $7,200,000, including spare parts.
Use of credit by customers of New York Stock Exchange firms held-about even in September, the Exchange has reported.
Glenn W. Clark has been elected president and director of the Mississippi River Fuel Corporation, St. Louis, Mo. He succeeds William G. Marbury, who becomes chairman of the board.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)-- The Eisenhower Administration is looking ahead to continuation of foreign aid.
Contract awards for heavy construction in the week ended yesterday amounted to $446,621,000. The Engineering News-Record and Construction Daily reported.
Capt. Piero Calamai conceded yesterday that Italian law required a shipmaster to make every possible effort to save his ship's books and papers before abandoning ship.

Dick Button, Tenley Albright and Carol Heiss will give figureskating exhibitions at the Good Will Ambassadors' Olympic Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria, Oct. 26, climax event of the New York City Olympic Committee's fundraising drive.
A clinic for insulation, air-conditioning and building contractors will be held by the Aluminum Company of America on Tuesday at 8 P.M. at the Hotel Pierre.

Net assets of 150 mutual funds and closed-end investment companies increased $695,558,000 in the first nine months of 1956 to $9732,167,000, the National Association of Investment Companies reported yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 18--The United States is prepared to announce new measures of support for the Suez Canal Users Association, authoritative sources said tonight.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 18 (AP) --The Government announced today that security forces in pre-dawn raids arrested about seventy persons engaged in a terrorist campaign. A spokesman declared the campaign was directed by former President Peron.
The Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad today announced a contract for studies of an atomic-powered locomotive.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 18 (UP) --The Toledo Blade endorsed Adlai E. Stevenson today. It was the first time in its 121-year history that the paper has supported a Democrat for the Presidency.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 18 --The "thaw" that set in in Hungary when Matyas Rakosi was deposed from the leadership of the Working People's (Communist party) continues unabated.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 18 (UP)-- The world champion New York Yankees' catcher was honored by his friends on "The Hill" today as "one of the three best-known Italians in the world--Columbus, Marconi and Yogi Berra."
The Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation achieved record sales and earnings in the first nine months this year, but earnings declined in the third quarter.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18--Grain and soybean futures declined at the opening today on the Board of Trade, but substantial commission buying entered the market, which turned prices strong for a time.
LONDON, Oct. 18--A leading British civil engineer said today that if the Aswan High Dam in Egypt were built it would become a "dwindling asset" because of silt.

Mrs. Julie Wurzburger Neumann of 12 Clark Street, Brooklyn, founder and director emeritus of the Brooklyn Ethical Culture School, died Thursday in the home of a sister, Mrs. Elsie W. Dewald, 418 Central Park West, after a long illness. Her age was 79.
Labor, management and Government must cooperate to allow people of all races and creeds to study and work together if "true democracy" is to function, Governor Harriman said yesterday.

POZNAN, Poland, Oct. 18 (Reuters)--The third and longest of the major trials arising from rioting here June 28 neared its end tonight with dramatic testimony about a 13-year-old boy killed during the fighting.

ALBANY, Oct. 18 (AP)--Governor Harriman appointed Angelo J. Martone of Glen Cove to the State Insurance Board today. Mr. Martone, a 51-year-old contractor, was named to succeed Samuel A. Berger of New York. Mr. Berger's three-year term expired last March. The appointment is subject to confirmation by the Senate.
NEWCOMERS to the State of Washington delight in the sound of Indian place names such as Suquamish, Snoqualmie, Snohomish, Kittitas, Klickitat, Wynooche and Wenatchee.

QUINCY, Mass., Oct. 18 (AP)-- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, described Adlai E. Stevenson tonight as "a professorial exGovernor who has never once in his life been called upon to make a decision of profound international importance."
DURING the last few years, Latin America has experi enced an intense wave of activity in the fine arts. The excitement of both artists and public has had a laudable effect.

TURKU, Finland, Oct. 18 (AP) --Using the Spanish Barra Vasca style, a young Finnish javelin thrower today made a throw of 86.70 meters (284 feet 5 2/5 inches), well beyond the world record. The listed record of 268 feet 2 inches is held by Bud Held of Los Angeles.

The investigation into charges of racketeering and monopoly in the private cartmen's industry here fanned out yesterday to include inquiries by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and States Attorney General Jacob K. Javits.
The Southern states are violating the law of the land in their attempt to maintain segregation, the American Civil Liberties Union charged yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 18--Alexei Roshchin, Soviet charge d'affaires, protested today against the refusal of the British authorities to allow Alexis Chwastov and his daughter Tanya, 2 years old, to sail for the Soviet Union last week. He made his protest to Anthony Nutting, Minister of State.
BONWIT TELLER is coddling mothers-to-be. With an eye to the holiday season ahead, it is using motherhood as an excuse to dress women in satin and brocade, ornamented with mink or fox.
Many women prominent in society have become patronesses for the Nov. 14 theatre benefit party of the Third Street Music Settlement.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage of Mrs. Martha Bayard Morrison and Willard Mason Rogers. The ceremony was performed last Friday in San Juan, P.R., in the Union Church by the Rev. Dr. Alfred Penney.
Federal mediators intervened yesterday in deadlocked contract negotiations between the Newspaper Guild of New York and seven major daily newspapers in this city.

Richie Guerin from Iona and Gary Bergen from Utah, both rookies, were named yesterday to start along with Ken Sears, Carl Braun and Ray Felix for the New York Knickerbockers against the College All-Stars in the professional basketball exhibition at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

"Father and Son," a Jewish folk play by F. Bimko, will be given tonight at the Labor Temple Theatre, 242 East Fourteenth Street. The cast includes Gustav Berger, Jacob Mestel, Max and Rose Bozik, Mina Bern, Ben Bonus and Israel Mandel.
It seemed to Stanley Frank yesterday that after twenty-five unhappy years the whole city was suddenly on his side.
The New York Central Railroad won the right yesterday to discontinue six little-used trains in northern New York but lost a bid to cancel five others.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 18 (AP) --A Communist mass meeting in the heart of Tel Aviv was broken up tonight by right-wing Herut party hecklers.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 18 (Reuters)--The Lower House of the Althing, Iceland's Parliament, today elected Einar Olgiersson, founder of the Icelandic Communist party, as its speaker. Mr. Olgeirsson has just returned from an annual trip to Moscow.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 18 (AP) --Elvis Presley, the singer, was involved in a fist fight with a service station manager today.
BALBOA, C.Z., Oct. 18--The Panama Line will soon offer for sale or charter the Panama, one of three sister ships sailing weekly from New York to Cristobal via Port au Prince.

DETROIT, Oct. 18--The Detroit Symphony, which used to play in the Masonic Auditorium, tonight gave its first concert in its new home. That home is the still unlandscaped and barely completed Henry and Edsel Ford Auditorium, the third of the buildings to be erected as part of the thirty-block civic center development along the Detroit River.
Substantial sales and promises of more to follow in the next few weeks were reported yesterday as the National Business Show went into closing stages in the Coliseum.
Twenty-five per cent of Negro Democratic voters have decided to vote for President Eisenhower, Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. declared yesterday.

Every field and complaint inspector who became an employe of the Islip, L.I., Building Department before January of this year has taken gratuities from builders, J. Irwin Shapiro, State Commissioner of Investigation, charged yesterday.

A new rolling mill designed to fabricate radioactive nuclear materials in an airtight enclosure that protects the operators was displayed for the first time yesterday in Long Island City, Queens, by its ...
Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that more than "a whole Police Department ringing doorbells" was needed to qualify for a seat in the United States Senate.
PEIPING, Oct. 18 (Reuters) H.S. Suhrawardy, Pakistani Prime Minister, flew here today for an eleven-day visit at the invitation of Chou En-lai, Premier of Communist China.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's speech at Portland, Ore., last night as recorded by The New York Times:

Columbia's 150-pound football team opens its season today against the University of Pennsylvania at Baker Field. This is the Lions' second season of Eastern Intercollegiate League lightweight competition.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)-- Dr. John B. Holden has been appointed specialist in adult education and the aging for the Office of Education.

The controversy precipitated by Mr. Stevenson's call for an end to all larger hydrogen bomb tests focuses attention again on the central problem that has thus far prevented any international disarmament agreement despite ten years of labor.
The General Foods Corporation in its half year ended Sept. 30 attained the highest sales and earnings for any similar period in its history, Charles G. Mortimer, president, reported.
Thirty-seven faculty members at City College, including fourteen scientists, "warmly endorsed" in a resolution yesterday Adlai E. Stevenson's proposal to halt further hydrogen bomb testing.

Bank clearings for the major cities of the nation totaled $20,847,079,000 for the week ended on Wednesday, 6 per cent above the preceding week's level but 13.6 per cent below the $24,115,514,000 turnover in the similar week last year, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

The Industrial Home for the Blind will conduct a conference today for teachers from elementary and high schools in Nassau County attended by blind children. The conference will be held at the institution's Burrwood home at Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 18--Grosvenor Atterbury, architect and inventor, died today in Southampton Hospital after a long illness. His age was 87. He was a resident of the Shinnecock Hills section of this community.

ROME, Oct. 18--The Italian Social Movement, the official name for the Neo-Fascist party, has warned its rank and file against "disunion." This was seen as open acknowledgement that Neo-Fascism was threatened by a split.

A story in The New York Times of Oct. 9 said that the Columbia University chapter of Students for Democratic Action had been suspended by the national organization for refusing to endorse Adlai E. Stevenson for the Presidency.
The appointment of Mrs. Maurice A. Selinger of Washington as general chairman of the fund-raising committee of Planned Parenthood Federation of America was announced yesterday.
A six-story store and apartment building at 58 St. Mark's Place has been sold by Estate Investors, Inc., after an ownership of several years, to Michael Anastasio.
Sales of the Crucible Steel Company of America are expected to reach a record high this year, despite the steel strike, according to Joel Hunter, president.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18--Representatives of eighty-two nations sitting here concluded tonight their study of a proposed statute for an international "atoms for peace" agency.

BERLIN, Oct. 18 (Reuters)-- Performance rights to Erich Maria Remarque's new play, "The Last Station," have been bought for the United States by Otto Preminger, film producer. Mr. Remarque is the author of the World War I novel "All Quiet on the Western Front."

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Pot up the rooted cuttings that were taken from house plants in early September. Put only one in each small-size clay pot. The soil mixture is two parts loam, one part humus and one part sand. After watering, place pots in a bright--not sunny--spot for one week.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 21-- Middle East violence suddenly swung back to Israel's Egyptian border today. Three Israeli soldiers were reported killed and twenty-sevens wounded in mine blasts.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 21--The entire steel products market has tightened up in the wake of heavier orders from automobile makers. Some car producers are asking for 100 per cent of their December steel sheet allotments. That compares with previous requirements ranging from 80 to 100 per cent of November's available automotive sheet space. Several weeks ago, all sheet makers had filled their books for November and most had sold out their sheet production for December.

A Urban Shirk, an inventor and industrial consultant, died Saturday afternoon after abdominal surgery at North Shore hospital, Manhasset, L.I. His age was 86. He lived at 251-37 Hand Road, Little Neck, Queens.

Mrs. Julia Early celebrated her 101st birthday yesterday afternoon with her wellwishers and commented, "You can't live forever, you know."
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Oct. 21--Dr. Julio Lozano Diaz was forced to resign today as Chief of State and turn the powers of govermnent over to a military junta.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 21 (AP)--Australia today named a track and field team of fiftythree men and twenty women for the Olympic Games starting here Nov. 22.
DETROIT, Oct. 21 (UP)--Vic Stasiuk fired a pair of goals tonight to lift the Boston Bruins from a two-goal deficit into a 3-3 tie with the Detroit Red Wings before 11,511 fans.

PERHAPS it is only in the Yiddish theatre that the problem of how much of one's ethnic identity should be dropped into the American melting pot can be offered in a play heavily larded with comedy and music. In any event, "It's a Funny World," presented Saturday night at the Downtown National Theatre, Second Avenue at Houston Street, was an unqualified success.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 21-- President Eisenhower was urged tonight, in the light of "widening cracks" in the Soviet power bloc, to make a personal effort to bring about a face-to-face meeting of the top leaders of the Arab states and Israel.
The Estate Securities Company Inc., has purchased the sixty-six-family apartment house at 7101 Bay Parkway in Brooklyn.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 (AP) --The unbeaten Chicago Cardinals intercepted six passes and recovered two fumbles to defeat the Philadelphia Eagles, 20--6, before 36,545 fans at Connie Mack Stadium today. It was the Cardinals' fourth straight National Football League victory.
The Daily Worker here editorially declares today that Poles are "advancing the democratization and independence of their Socialist regime."

Once more the Mayor's Slum Clearance Committee, of which Robert Moses is chairman, has shown courage and imagination in designing a slum clearance project. This time it is the $7,745,030 middleincome housing for downtown Manhattan to be bounded by Chatham Square, St. James Place, Pearl Street and Park Row. Hard by the Brooklyn Bridge, the project will be handy to City Hall, the Municipal Building and several other public structures.
Eugene E. Early of 17 East Ninety-sixth Street, publisher of The Queens Evening News and an active newspaper man for half a century, died yesterday in Metropolitan Hospital. His age was 67.

FRESNO, Calif., Oct. 21-- Senator Estes Kefauver urged today that the United States negotiate with Premier Nikolai Bulganin of the Soviet Union on the Russian's proposal for calling off hydrogen-bomb tests.
WARSAW, Oct. 21--The official organ of the Polish Communist Central Committee struck back sharply today at criticisms of the Polish press that appeared yesterday in the Soviet newspaper Pravda.

TO describe the pastries at Desserts, Inc., as homemade does them justice only if the comparison is with prize winning cakes, pies and cookies at country fairs. Take the apple turnovers ($1.50 a dozen). They are dainty half-moons to consume in two bites. The tart apple filling is encased in a flaky pastry tangy with cheese.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21-- James G. Cross of Baltimore, president of the International Union of Bakery and Confectionery, Workers, was released on $5,000 bail today after having been held on suspicion of kidnap ping and assault.
BABY DOLL, with seventyfive-foot legs and eightfoot eyebrows, is emerging in brave color, day by day, on a block-long billboard on the west side of Times Square.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21-- President Eisenhower angrily denounced today Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin's latest letter urging an end of tests of nuclear weapons.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21--Adlai E. Stevenson's proposal to end testing of hydrogen bombs was endorsed today by seventy-three scientists at the Argonne National Laboratory, Lemont, Ill.

A week ago this column addressed itself to the theme that in the case of most countries of the free world the last decade had seen an unmistakable change in the general attitude toward inflation. The preponderance of evidence, it was observed, indicated that not only the financial and political leaders but the people as a whole had become increasingly conscious of inflation's forewarnings and increasingly aware of the seriousness of its social implications.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21--Today's White House accusation that the Soviet Union was interfering in this country's internal political affairs recalls a similar charge against the British for an incident that occurred sixtyeight years ago today.

"CAMERA THREE" consistently an interesting program because of its willingness to try new approaches, did another impressive job yesterday. The theme of the show, presented over. Channel 2, was "The United Nations: Extraordinary Session."
On West 120th Street, between Riverside Drive and Claremont Avenue, two unfamiliar square portals gape like the entry to just-discovered catacombs.
Attorney General Jacob K. Javits scotched rumor's yesterday that he had changed his religion.

Although Honduras has made steady progress toward political democracy, her internal situation has been complicated and increasingly tense since October, 1954. It was at the close of 1954, as a result of an electoral impasse, that Dr. Julio Lozano Diaz came to power.

The Radio and Television Directors Guild has charged the National Broadcasting Company with a violation of contract because the network credited William Wyler as director of Somerset Maugham's drama "The Letter."
TANGIER, Morocco, Oct. 21-- Adjournment last night of a nine-power conference on the liquidation of the international administration of Tangier has left undecided the economic status of this city.

ROME, Oct. 21 (AP)--Jean Behra of France drove a Maserati to victory today in the 2,000-C.C. sport car event in the Grand Prix of Rome auto races. Luigi Villoresi of Italy crashed and was hurt during the competition.

A draw in thirty moves with Herbert Seidman, champion of the Marshall Chess Club, in the ninth round of the Lessing J. Rosenwald trophy tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday enabled Samuel Reshevsky to remain in the lead. with two rounds to go.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21--Adlai E. Stevenson charged tonight that the White House had dismissed Soviet proposals to end hydrogen bomb tests "out of hand" instead of giving "sober consideration" to all possibilities to reduce the threat of war.

The Russians have previously indicated their interest in stopping H-bomb explosions. Although there appears to be nothing new in Mr. Bulganin's [Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Premier] latest communication, it is encouraging that Russia appears to be still disposed to curb these dreadful weapons.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Oct. 21-- Joe Vileno, the pro at Aldecress, and Mrs. Judy Atkins, an Aldecress member, won the second annual Dellwood Country Club open mixed Scotch foursome tournament today. The team scored a 2-and-1 triumph over the amateur pair of Jack Moone and Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood in the final round scheduled for 18 holes.

Sylvan L. Hanauer, deputy Commissioner of the Air Pollution Control Department, said last night that a budget increase for his department would look small when compared with the savings it could effect.
LONDON, Oct. 21 (Reuters) --Three new 20,000-ton ships that Royal Mail Lines, Ltd., will bring into service within the next four years will strengthen Britain's position on the South American run.
President Eisenhower was criticized yesterday by Governor Harriman for his attitude on Adlai E. Stevenson's proposal "to explore ways to stop the deadly hydrogen bomb race."

WASHINGTON, Oct 21 (AP)-- The Presidential candidate of the Socialist Workers Party said today that de-Stalinization and other "great new developments within the Soviet orbit" were "shaking up the whole radical movement" in the United States.
Claude Benham, Tommy Morris and Jimmy Brown were magic names in Saturday's football news.

PENNSYLVANIA'S motto is "Virtue, Liberty and Inde pendence." The mountain laurel is its official flower. Its tree is the hemlock, and its bird is the ruffed grouse. Last April, except for a balky Legislature, it would have had an official dog--the Great Dane.
LETITIA BALDRIGE, a blonde young woman for whom op portunity has opened many doors will add another to her list of achievements next month.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 21--Charles Vachris, a quarterback, threw four touchdown passes, three to Larry Eisenhauer, an end, as Chaminade routed Iona Prep, 33--12, at Haag Field today. A crowd of 6,000 saw the game.
Steve Allen, a television humorist, preached a sermon yesterday. He occupied the pulpit of the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity at Central Park West and Seventy-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UP) --Vice President Richard M. Nixon got in much relaxation today before the start tomorrow of his third and final crosscountry campaign tour.
RAY BOLGER inaugurated a new program called "Wash ington Square" at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon over Channel 4; the bad luck that has dogged the gifted dancer on television is still with him.
BERLIN, Oct. 2--West German political leaders see events in Poland as strengthening pressures that exist in East Germany for a measure of independence.
LOS ANGELES, Oct, 21--Interest rates are likely to move higher before they move lower, Fred F. Florence, president of the American Bankers Association, said today.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 21--Rarely have the issues been so clear as in the race for Representative in the Twenty-seventh Congressional District of Putnam and western Westchester Counties.

Not a single space ship has been built or launched--not even one to go to the near-by Moon. The 1956 Open Team-of-Four Championship, the final event of the annual three-day Metropolitan Championships held at the McAlpin Hotel, was won early today by the defending champions.

McCoy Pighee, who collected thirty-nine traffic tickets last year and chose an eighty-sevenday jail sentence instead of a $1,900 fine, has been accused of reviving his collection. This time, the police said last night, it amounts to fourteen unanswered summonses.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UP) --The fired-up Washington Redskins gave another shove to Cleveland's tottering football dynasty today by belting the Browns, 20--9, before 23,332 fans.

TOKYO, Oct. 21 (AP)--Don Newcombe received another early battering today as the Japan All-Stars, perhaps the strongest Japanese team ever assembled, whipped the Brooklyn Dodgers, 6-1, in an exhibition game.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UP) --President Eisenhower, replying to Democratic criticism, revealed today that he planned to ask Congress next year to give small-business men about $600,000,000 in tax relief.

The new 556-bed Coney Island Hospital began yesterday to receive 185 patients from the old 250-bed Coney Island Hospital. The transfer is expected to end today.

City Councilman Hugh Quinn's connection with a private carting concern doing business with the city came under inquiry yesterday by Investigation Commissioner Charles H. Tenney. The inquiry was ordered by Mayor Wagner.

PARIS, Tuesday, Oct. 23-- Premier Guy Mollet summoned his top ministerial, aides to a meeting here at 1 A. M. to consider the implications of the dramatic arrest of five top leaders of the Algerian rebellion last night.

The 1957 Chrysler line features reductions in over-all length, width and height and increases in horsepower ratings. The cars announced yesterday by the Chrysler Division of the Chrysler Corporation will go on display next Tuesday.

IN "Goodbye, Gray Flannel," which was presented last night on the Robert Montgom- ery hour over Channel 4, J. Harvey Howells had the ingredients for an above-average video comedy. But for some reason, it didn't play quite so effectively as it should have.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed unchanged to 13 points (65 cents a bale) higher than on Friday. Volume was small.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22--The creation of a national economic council to determine and coordinate economic policies of the Government and to report directly to the President was recommended today by Elliott V. Bell, chairman of the executive committee of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company.
Japanese bicycle manufacturers formally started yesterday a campaign to win a market in the United States.

Former State Senator Benjamin Antin, a Democrat who represented the twenty-second Senatorial District of the Bronx in 1923-30, died yesterday morning at his home, 601 East Twentieth Street, after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

Mayor Wagner called yesterday for greater use of a "middle road" to provide housing for middle-income families. LOUISVILLE, Ky. Oct. 22The warring factions of the Democratic party in Kentucky gave their first public demonstration today of the truce that many hope will spell defeat for the Republicans in the Nov. 6 election.

BAY SHORE, L. L, Oct. 22Gil Cavanaugh, 30--year--old Rockaway Hunt Club professional, won his first major golfing event today. He captured the Long Island Professional Golfers Association championship with a thirty-six-hole score of 140 at the Southward Ho Country Club.
Joseph Peter Carlino, one of the seven men indicted with Johnny Dio in the acid blinding of victor Riesel, pleaded guilty yesterday in a night session of United States District Court.

ON the coast of Massachusetts, Cape Cod protrudes sixty-five miles out into the Atlantic from the mainland like a beckoning finger, summoning the adventurous and the oppressed to the shores of America.

Major New York City banks may move soon to become the chief units of holding companies with operations both in the city and in suburban areas such as Nassau and Westchester Counties. The banks are restricted now to the five New York City boroughs.

Stocks lost a little ground yesterday in a market that showed almost no life. Volume of 1,430,000 shares compared with 1,719,250 on Friday and was the smallest since Oct. 12, Of the 1,101 issues traded, 515 fell, 348 rose and 238 closed unchanged.

Approval by the Art Commission of a new mural depicting family life has been announced by Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen. A BIBLIOGRAPHY of children's books that was two years in the making has just been published by the American Jewish Committee. Housing and redevelopment officials from cities across the nation said yesterday that the Federal Government was not doing enough for public housing and against slums.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 24 (AP) --Mrs. E.H. Augustus paid $10,500 today for a brown colt by Cosmic Bomb-Last of All during the afternoon session of Keeneland's fall sales of thoroughbred yearlings. Hurstland Farm consigned the colt.

Four women who have been designated "Women of Achievement of 1956" will receive the Medallion of Honor, highest award of the Women's National Institute. The presentations will be made Nov. 5 at the thirtythird annual Women's International Exposition at the Seventyfirst Regiment Armory.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 24 (AP)--The Gregorian calendar will be used in India for all official purposes beginning next March 22, the start of the Hindu modern-era year 1879. While the Gregorian is standard in the Western world, a variety of calendars are used in India.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct 24 --Miss Barbara Jeanne Schapiro and Edward Berman will be married in February. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Max Schapiro. The prospective bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Berman of Bayonne.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 24 --Russell Sambrook of 233 Ridge Road, Rutherford, commercial artist and illustrator, died this morning in Hackensack-Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 64.
Ray Beck, one of the stalwarts of the New York Giants' defense, may handle one of the offensive guard spots when the Giants face the Philadelphia Eagles at Yankee Stadium on Sunday.
WANTAGH, L.I., Oct. 24 (AP) --The Rochester Royals led all the way in defeating the New York Knickerbockers, 83--79 in an exhibition game between National Basketball Association teams tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (U.P.) --Six whooping cranes have safely completed the flight from their Canadian breeding grounds to the Arkansas wildlife refuge in Texas, the Fish and Wildlife Service reported today.
A registrations statement covering $170,593,900 debentures of the Sinclair Oil Corporation will be filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission, P.C.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24 (AP).--A six-foot, 220-pound nursemaid charged with killing two babies switched her plea from innocent to guilty today without a sign of emotion.

Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Zionist Organization, last night received the Hebrew University-Solomon Bublick public service award for 1956 in recognition of his efforts in behalf of Israel.

Who invented the lightning rod--Benjamin Franklin of the United States or Prokop Divis of Czechoslovakia? Soviet Russia and its Czech satellite seem to be at odds over the answer. Stamps issued by the two countries--Russia's was received here yesterday from Moscow--emphasize the disagreement.

A three-year experimental program to train future clergymen in acting, directing and playwriting was opened yesterday at Union Theological Seminary under a $55,000 grant from the Rockefeller Foundation.
It will require a major reversal in form for the Republicans to unseat Representative Victor L. Anfuso in Brooklyn's Eighth Congressional District.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 24 --Wolfgang Wostl scored at 13 minutes of the fourth period to enable the City College soccer team to gain a double overtime tie, 2--2, with Army on Clinton, Field today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP)-- President Eisenhower will send a special message to the United Nations Friday in connection with a ceremony creating an international agency to promote peaceful uses of atomic energy.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 24-- Dr. Stanley Gibson, former chief of staff of Children's Memorial Hospital and retired head of the department of pediatrics of the Northwestern University School of Medicine, died today in Veterans Research Hospital. He was 73 years old.
Governor Harriman appealed last night for election of Adlai E. Stevenson as President as the means for uniting free nations to take advantage of Soviet weakening in Poland and Hungary.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 24-- The Soviet visitors observing the American election campaign witnessed tonight a typical feature of American grassroots politics --a debate between two Congressional candidates.
ALBANS, Oct. 24 (AP)--The State University of New York reported today that its thirty eight colleges had 31,702 fulltime undergraduates. The enrollment a year ago was 29,908.

LONDON, Oct. 24--President Tito of Yugoslavia is said to have agreed during his recent talks with Soviet leaders at Yalta that he would not try to influence Poland, Czechoslovakia and East Germany to follow their own roads to socialism.

DRAWING more sidewalk superintendents than a con struction crew is a plate-glass window fronting a new cosmetic shop at 510 Madison Avenue. Here unperturbed customers sit at a pink counter for make-up analysis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24-- Sharp increases in duties on imported velveteens were reccommended today to President Eisenhower by the Tariff Commission. The rise was urged as necessary to protect velveteen producers in the nation's cotton textile industry.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday that his office would begin presenting evidence tomorrow to a New York County grand jury on a "black market" in the Salk polio vaccine.

A jazz band that is without a peer could be heard from time to time last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in the first of a series of concerts entitled "Jazz at the Academy." The band was Duke Ellington's, and it played to a sparsely settled auditorium.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP)-- The chairman of the Veterans Advisory Committee of the Democratic National Committee said today that the Eisenhower Administration had given veterans "the run-around."

CHICAGO, Oct. 24--Capt. Jones F. Devlin Jr., general manager of the United States Lines, and Leslie H. Quackenbush, vice president of States Marine Corporation, were named today general chairman and executive general chairman, respectively, of National Safety Council's marine section.
LONDON, Oct. 24--The War Office said that 187 Army reservists, of a draft of 1,359, failed to report to the troopship Asturias today after a sevenday home leave from Germany.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UP) --The Republican National Committee issued today a pamphlet called "Which Stevenson Can You Believe?"

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24--A poll conducted by The Daily Pennsylvanian, campus publication, today showed students at the University of Pennsylvania favored President Eisenhower for re-election over Adlai E. Stevenson.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 24-- The Republic of Vietnam will celebrate its first anniversary Friday by promulgating a Constitution that gives the President broad powers and outlaws communism.
A new globe of the Earth is turning on its axis in a West Side workshop. Six feet in diameter, it shows no political divisions, only the world's geological formations and one city--Toronto.

Deposits in the 527 mutual savings banks of the country rose $1,340,000,000 during the first nine months of 1956 to reach a new high of $29,522,000,000 on Sept. 30, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday. The gain was 2 per cent less than the, increase reported in the same 1955 period.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 24 (AP) --The Kentucky Racing Commission today rejected Eddie Arcaro's plea that a ten-day suspension meted him be lightened.

The 1956-57 finance campaign of the Young Men's Christian Association of the City of New York will be directed by Henry G. Waltemade, president of Henry Waltemade, Inc. The campaign, which has a goal of $542,845, will open on Monday and extend through January, 1957.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 24-- Vermont's tradition of supporting the Republican candidate for President in every election since the party was organized 100 years ago undoubtedly will be continued on Nov. 6. The Republican majority, however, may be smaller than in 1952.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (U.P.)-- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, asked Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. today if he allowed Justice Department officials to speculate in stocks of concerns they were supposed to watch for possible anti-trust violations.
Daystrom, Inc., manufacturer of electronic, electrical and other equipment, has announced the election of Chester F. Smith as a director.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday an 8.4 per cent gain in electric revenues for the twelve months ended Sept. 30. This resulted in a 7.8 per cent rise in total operating revenues, to $158,280,775 from $146,841,765 the year before.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24--The State Department had no contact today with the United States Legation in Budapest.

ROME, Oct. 24 (AP)--A mounted statue of Gen. Jose de San Martin presented to the city of Rome six years ago by Italians living in Argentina finally was unveiled today.

ENID, Okla, Oct. 24 (AP)--A ten-mile stretch of U.S. Route 64 near the town of Jet was closed shortly before noon today as a dust storm cut visibility to zero. The highway patrol was stopping traffic after a threecar accident. No one was hurt seriously.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation yesterday became the first of the big domestic copper mining concerns since last July to cut prices. The company trimmed its copper price 4 cents a pound to 36 cents, effective with shipments today.
The lower and more powerful 1957 Plymouth car line was announced yesterday by the Plymouth division of the Chrysler Corporation. The cars will go on display Tuesday.
BERLIN, Oct, 24 (AP)--Communist East Germany kept security troops and policemen on special alert today to guard against any possible anti-Soviet outbreaks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24-- Qualified Negro voters are being purged by the thousands from the election rolls of at least five Southern states, a Department of Justice official said today.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 24 (AP) --A 31-year-old woman tonight became the first woman to be ordained into the ministry of the Presbyterian Church in the United States.

KARLSRUHE, Germany, Oct. 25 (Reuters)--The treason trial of Dr. Otto John, former West German security chief, will open here before the Federal Court Nov. 12, it was announced today. It is expected to take three to four weeks. About fifty-five witnesses are expected to testify.
LONDON, Oct. 24--Henry Nicholas Ridley, originator of Malaya's rubber industry, died here today. He celebrated his 100th birthday last December.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24-- The only reservation in official Washington about the antiSoviet revolts in Poland and Hungary is that they may be moving too fast.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UP)-- Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, objected today to Navy plans to establish a practical aerial mine-laying range on the coast of Maine near the mouth of the Kennebec River.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 (AP)-- Los Angeles County's population has swelled by 50,000 in the last year, the Regional Planning Commission estimates. This brings the county total, as of July 1, to 5,342,755, the commission reported yesterday. Los Angeles City, which added 18,157, has 2,277,997 residents, the commission said.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24--Senate investigators were told today that officers of the 81,000 ton British liner Queen Mary had risked her forfeiture to the United States by carrying an infant from New York toward a Soviet destination.

Passengers on ten airlines will soon need only one timetable for heavily traveled routes. Starting Sunday, airline passengers will be able to flip through a simple, consolidated timetable listing all the flights of most major airlines in a format similar to those furnished to suburban railroad commuters.
