New York city streets have been the safest ever in the last two years, Mayor Wagner de clared yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 24--(Reuters)-- Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, exiled former Polish premier, said here today that the aim of the Communist reshuffle in Poland is to confuse Western public opinion and gain economic aid to save the Communist system.
Earnings of the General Motors Corporation in the first nine months of this year fell 29.9 per cent below the 1955 figure. Dollar sales were off 15 per cent.

NEWARK, Del., Oct. 24 (AP)-- The college football career of the University of Delaware center, Jerry Weis, a senior of South River, N.J., ended today. X-rays showed that he had suffered a fractured ankle in practice.
The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company attained the highest sales and earnings in its history in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30, according to the report released for publication today.

LONDON, Oct. 24--The Soviet Union has offered to expand trade with Poland as part of an attempt to tighten economic ties with the newly independent Titoist regime.
MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 24--An assault charge against Michael P. Grace 2d, shipping heir, was dismissed for lack of evidence here today in First District Court.

LONDON, Oct. 24--The British Government announced today it had authorized the nationalized British Overseas Airways Corporation to buy fifteen Boeing-707 jet airliners. They will be powered by Rolls-Royce Conway engines.
The New York Public Library announced yesterday the election of Bethuel M. Webster to its board of trustees.

LONDON, Oct. 24--King Hussein's remarks about the BritishJordanian treaty produced no official reaction here today. A Foreign Office representative said there could be no comment "until we get an official communication."

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 24 (AP)-- In ceremonies described by Governor Harriman as a "milestone in the fight against tuberculosis," the Herman M. Biggs State Tuberculosis Hospital was transferred to Tompkins County today for general hospital purposes.
The Nov. 13 performance of Terence Rattigan's "Separate Tables" will benefit the Citizens Committee for Children. The play, starring Eric Portman and Margaret Leighton, is at the Music Box.

VIENNA, Oct. 24--According to a Vienna eyewitness, demonstrators in Budapest threw the twenty-four-foot statue of Stalin from its pedestal early today. Earlier attempts last night to drag it down with the aid of winches and chains had failed.

ALBANY, Oct. 24 (AP)--More than 7,700,000 New Yorkers are registered for the Nov. 6 Presidential election, the second highest turnout in history. Suburban areas made a strong showing.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 24 (AP)-- Calumet Farm's classy 4-yearold gelding, Bardstown, stepped to the front as a field of seven star thoroughbreds straightened into the home stretch and went on to win the $81,400 Trenton Handicap by a neck from Summer Tan at Garden State Park today.

DETROIT, Oct. 24 (AP)--The United Auto Workers union has asked a Senate subcommittee to investigate the "publication, as an advertisement," of an editorial from The Minneapolis Star and Tribune, endorsing President Eisenhower and Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
NORWICH, N.Y., Oct. 24-- Attorney General Jacob K. Javits attacked today his Democratic opponent, Mayor Wagner of New York, as a film believer in "the Tammany philosophy."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (U.P.)-- The First Marine Division received the Presidential Unit Citation and the Navy Unit Commendation today for its Korean war service.

NAHA, Okinawa, Thursday, Oct. 25 (AP)--Shuhei Higa, chief of the government of the Ryukyu Islands, died early today of a heart attack, the United States Army announced. His age was 54. He was the top Okinawan official in the island chain south of Japan.

MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 24 (UP) --Unbeaten and untied Tufts today declined an opportunity to compete in the Refrigerator Bowl football game at Evansville, Ind. "We don't compete in post-season games; they are not within the realm of our athletic policy," the athletic committee said.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 24 (UP) --President Carlos Ibanez del Campo accepted today the resignation of Mariano Fontecilla, Minister of Justice, and named Arturo Zuniga la Torre to succeed him. Senor Zuniga la Torre had been Minister of Economy and Finance in one of President Ibanez' previous cabinets.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct, 24 (UP) --The Wheatley Stable's Bold Ruler, the favorite, arrived today for next Saturday's $315,000 Garden State Stakes, the world's richest race, Which is expected to attract nineteen juvenile colts. Bold Ruler will be racing the mile-and-sixteenth distance for the first time.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 25--It is "hardly conceivable" that the Soviet puppet Government of East Germany will remain unaffected by the anti-Soviet uprisings in East Europe, a Bonn Government commentary said today.
The Sperry Gyroscope Company, center of a violent monthlong strike last year, entered into a long-term peace agreement with its 9,500 union employes yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 7 to 20 points (35 cents to $1 a bale) off.
ONE American is represented in the diverse group show of paintings, drawings and colleges at the Rose Fried Gallery, 40 East Sixty-eighth Street.

ABOUT a year age Tom Manning, historian at ven erable Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, discovered the unmarked grave of Capt. Samuel Chester Reid, who designed the stars and stripes that first flew at the Capitol in Washington in 1818.
"PLAYHOUSE 90" reverted last night to grade B movie material. Even seeing it on the small home screen didn't help very much.

PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 25 (UP)--Tom Robbins of Larchmont, N.Y., broke par for the third straight day today to beat Roy G. Elliott of Cincinnati, 4 and 3, and move into the upper bracket semi-finals of the North and South senior golf championship.

These are days of celebration in Saigon. The first anniversary of the proclamation of the free Republic of Vietnam is being observed. Even more important, this time has been chosen for the promulgation of Vietnam's new Constitution, freely drafted and freely ratified.
A mother and her son were killed instantly and two women injured seriously yesterday afternoon when an automobile jumped a curb at Seventieth Avenue and Queens Boulevard in Forest Hills, Queens.

Directors of Mack Trucks, Inc., announced yesterday a four-for-three split of the common stock. The new stock will be issued on Dec. 10 to holders of record Nov. 19. The board also declared a cash dividend of 45 cents a share on the common stock to cover the first quarter of 1957. It will be paid March 15 to stockholders of record March 1.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 25-- Adolf Hitler was formally declared dead today.
THE world's largest fashion show opens tomorrow at the Coliseum, and it promises to be a whopper in every way.
BERNARDSTON, Mass., Oct. 25--This is what happened today and what was said, and if there is a moral in it let a moralist find it.

GARDNER READ'S Toccata Giocosa, Op. 94, is an un pretentious but engaging piece for full orchestra. Commissioned by the Louisville Philharmonic, it was introduced to New York by the Philharmonic-Symphony at Carnegie Hall last night.
An open-eyed representation of the figure of Justice, in the Criminal Courts Building, aroused the indignation of two courtroom spectators yesterday.
The scholarship fund of the Society of Mayflower Descendants will benefit from the society's annual dinner dance, to be held next Wednesday in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.
The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that a major group of American steamship companies had formally agreed to limit their ancient right to "log" seamen.

WARSAW, Oct. 25--Polish militiamen fired tear gas into a crowd threatening to attack Soviet Army installations in Legnica (Liegnitz) yesterday. Legnica is a Silesian headquarters town of the Soviet Army forces in Poland.
The theatre benefit committee of the William Alanson White Institute has announced that it has taken over the orchestra of the Coronet Theatre for the Nov. 27 performance of "The Sleeping Prince."

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 25--Parliament Square in Budapest became a battlefield shortly after noon today when a Soviet tank opened fire on a few thousand peaceful demonstrators whose only weapons were Hungarian flags.
UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 25--Mayor Wagner accused the Eisenhower Administration tonight of ignoring the problems of workers and communities impoverished by the flight of industry to the South.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25--Israel assured the Security Council today that she would never start a war with her Arab neighbors. But Israel also warned that she would not "sit back and suffer the consequences of a unilateral Arab belligerency."
In an effort to be of help to the independent voter we present herewith the first of a series of comments on the Congressional races within the general area of metropolitan New York.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--The National Education Association announced today its Centennial Commission of twenty-one members.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25-- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday, totaled 828,741 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation has reduced its price of refined copper 4 cents a pound, to 36 cents, effective with shipments today.
The Koehring Company of Milwaukee will acquire the Buffalo-Springfield Roller Company of Springfield, Ohio, effective Dec. 1, it was announced yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 25 (AP)--Nino Valdes of Cuba spoiled Bob Woodall's hopes with a knockout at 2:51 of the third round of their heavyweight fight, tonight at the Arena after sending the Bostonian to the canvas three times in the second.

Atomic energy experts are convinced that the "probability of a reactor catastrophe is so remote that the chance of its happening is almost zero," according to W.J. Satterfield, Jr., chief of the Atomic Energy Commission's insurance section.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 25 (AP)--The Federal Court of Appeals ruled today in a test case that administrators desegregating public schools had a Federal right to be free from "direct and deliberate interference."
Charles Dillon (Casey) Stengel, who guided his New York Yankees to a runaway in the 1956 pennant race, yesterday was named American League manager of the year by a wide margin.
Leaders of the Motormen's Benevolent Association were reported last night to be planning another subway strike on the eve of Election Day.
Edward R. Murrow's "Person to Person" program has granted equal time for Jinx Falkenburg to answer Shelley Winters.
Copper futures climbed 115 to 135 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. This was the first rise in the last six trading days.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 25 (AP)-- Nick Shuk and Richard Lawless shared riding honors on the second program of the Laurel race course season today. Shuk piloted four winners, and Lawless was in the saddle when Evelyn Miss captured the featured Capitol Hill Purse.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 25 (AP)--Altmeister, a slick chestnut gelding, tonight earned $5,309 for his owner, Charles Dennehy Jr., Lake Forest, Ill., in a $10,000 jumping sweepstakes at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.
The crowd loved it at Madison Square Garden last night.

The Assembly of Captive European Nations, representing democratic exiles from nine countries behind the Iron Curtain, called on the Security Council of the United Nations yesterday to condemn Soviet "intervention" in Eastern Europe.

The stoniest-faced observers at the Republican rally in Madison Square Garden last night were the three Russians and three Rumanians who had come to this country to study the American election campaign.

Primary production of aluminum in India, now about 8,000 long tons of ingots a year, will be nearly doubled by 1961, a leader of the Indian industry forecast yesterday.
Realty trading reported in the Bronx yesterday included the purchases of sites for new buildings.
YONKERS, Oct. 25 (AP)--Gardner Hanover, owned by T.J. Zornow of Pittsford, N.Y., and driven by Levi Harner, won, tonight's Arcadia Pace before 14,302 fans at Yonkers Raceway.
The Board of Education plans to ask the city for higher teacher salaries.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--The Navy disclosed today that an experimental jet fighter was hit and downed by its own cannon fire off Long Island last month.

LONDON, Oct. 25--In general, most sections of the stock market were quiet today and prices tended to fall. Government funds were a firm exception, with gains ranging up to 5s (70 cents).

MONTREAL, Oct. 25 (UP)-- The Toronto Maple Leafs rallied for two goals in the third period to trip the Montreal Canadiens, 3--2, tonight. Toronto moved into third place undisputed in the National Hockey League.

Villanova University and Florida State University are pulling out all the stops to make their Olympic Fund benefit football game at Philadelphia's Municipal Stadium tomorrow night one of the season's memorable spectacles.

Two illustrated books about the American frontier will be published next week. PrenticeHall will issue on Monday "The Old West Speaks," by Howard R. Driggs, a reconstruction of the Western expansion based on stories the author heard during his lifetime.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. showed a 11.79 per cent decline in its third-quarter net income from the similar period a year ago. This reduced the net for the nine months by 3.76 per cent, according to the earnings report issued for publication today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26--One of the largest inland harbor improvements in the country is nearing completion here.
Los Angeles movie houses are to get still more television competition from the showing of theatrical films on KTTV, leading independent station in Southern California.

The public market for new capital weathered another heavy period this week, with the trend in yields on new issues of prime investment securities continuing upward. This was particularly true in the field of local government financing, where new issues are coming to market daily in large volume.

Opera-lovers were already lining up yesterday morning at the Metropolitan Opera House for standing-room admission to Bellini's "Norma." This opera will open the season Monday night with Maria Meneghini Callas making her debut in the title role. The standing room does not go on sale until Monday night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26--The State Department disclosed today that the United States was consulting with Britain, France and other friendly governments on "the feasibility and advisability of bringing the situation in Hungary before the United Nations."

Universities were urged last night to seek new sources of in come for research rather than to rely on Federal and industrial grants.

Edward T. McCormick, president of the American Stock Exchange, yesterday registered objections to the action of the Securities and Exchange Commission in suspending trading in United States markets in the $1 par value common stock of Great Sweet Grass Oils, Ltd., a Canadian issue, for the next ten days.
MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., Oct. 26--The Rev. Dr. Charles S. Macfarland, secretary emeritus of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, died today after a long illness. His age was 89.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 26-- Prefabricated synagogues were proposed today as a solution to the need for suburban religious facilities caused by the movement of large numbers of Jewish people from the city.

Over the border in booming Canada, Canadians note that their money has risen in value to the highest point since February, 1955. Their dollar is now worth 1.03 1/16 of the United States dollar. Such a rise spells out better than words the good times they are enjoying.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 26-- South Vietnam promulgated its Constitution today as the high point of a celebration marking the nation's first anniversary as a free republic.

A new series, designated the Firesweep, has been added to the 1957 De Soto car line, which was announced yesterday by the DeSoto division of the Chrysler Corporation. The addition of the five new models expands the full line to fifteen models, the largest offered in the division's twentyeight-year history.

Morse, Under Secretary of Agriculture, defended the Administration today against allegations that the Government might have to "pay a pretty price" for 35,000,000 bushels of surplus wheat stored in tents put up by a commercial storage firm. PARIS, Nov. 13--A vigorous attack on the Suez policy of Premier Guy Mollet was made tonight by his former political ally, Pierre Mendes-France. The former Premier spoke at a rally of the Radical party.

CHESTER, N.J., Nov. 13-- Mr. and Mrs. Percy Chubb have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Corinne Roosevelt Robinson Chubb, to C. Austin Buck. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Jerome Buck of Far Hills.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13--An Alabama law and a city ordinance requiring segregation of races on intrastate buses were declared invalid by the Supreme Court today.

LONDON, Nov. 13--The British Government views Soviet military aid to Egypt as part of a continuing process the maximum objective of which is conquest.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 13 (AP)--Cy Young of Modesto, Calif., who set the Olympic Javelin throw record in 1952, bettered it by nearly 14 feet with a warm-up throw of 256 feet today.
POCONO MANOR, Pa., Nov. 13--The House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church overwhelmingly turned down today a proposal to elect and consecrate a Bishop for the armed forces.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 13-- Air pollution and not cigarette smoking was held probably responsible today for the increase in deaths from lung cancer in the United States.
WARSAW, Nov, 13--Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky was stripped of his titles as Poland's Minister of Defense and chief of the armed forces today.

The New York City Housing Authority would pay nearly 65 per cent more for electricity in most of its projects under billing charges proposed by Consolidated Edison.

A group of Lincoln Square presidents and business men filed a petition yesterday with the Federal Government to kill the $175,000,000 redevelopment of eighteen city blocks in that area.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- Like most wives, Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower--whom crowds and confidants affectionately call "Mamie"--makes dream plains for a permanent home, for folksy get-togethers in a place the heart knows is home.

LONDON, Nov. 13--The stock market remained dull today despite the optimism expressed in Chancellor of the Exchequer Harold Macmillan's speech in the economic debate in the House of Commons yesterday and the recovery in Wall Street.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 13-- An Israeli soldier was killed and three were wounded yesterday in a mine blast near the Syrian border, Army headquarters reported tonight.

The historic round-the-world trip of Charles Darwin that helped him formulate his theory of evolution will be retraced in 1958.
Plastic contribution boxes were installed yesterday in the Fifth Avenue building of the New York Public Library as quiet reminders that the institution had opened its annual drive for funds.

PORT SAID, Egypt, Nov. 13 --Ten United Nations observers landed at Port Said early this morning. They were transported here from Halfa, Israel, aboard a British LST (Landing Ship, Tank).

Third-quarter net profit of the International Paper Company declined 5.78 per cent from a year ago, but earnings for the nine months increased 6.1 per cent to a new high of $61,762,602.

TAMPICO, Mexico, Nov. 13 (AP)--A Texas shrimp boat captain wounded by rifle fire from a Mexican cutter was taken to a hospital here late today.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 13-- There is an ever-present danger of war in Korea, but there is little real evidence that a resumption of shooting is imminent.

Newark, N.J., raised $12,500,000 in the public bond market yesterday by the sale of general obligation bonds maturing serially from 1957 to 1976. The borrowing was to finance various public improvements.

A contract has been awarded for preliminary architectural studies for a new engineering center in mid-Manhattan intended to make New York the engineering capital of the world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)-- The Supreme Court today decided a United States company found to have violated the Sherman Antitrust Act by a cartel arrangement may be required to compete in foreign territories that had been allocated to companies abroad.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.L., Nov. 13--Fraser Macpherson Horn, a lawyer of 117 East Seventy-second Street, New York, and Wickapog Road, Southampton, died this morning at the Southampton Hospital after a long illness. He was 55 years old.

R.H. Macy Co., Inc., set a new record of $107,000,000 in sales in the thirteen weeks ended Oct. 27. This was an increase of 12 per cent over the $95,400,000 volume for the corresponding first quarter of the previous fiscal year, Jack I. Straus, board chairman, reported at the annual stockholder meeting here yesterday.
Bowling made its debut ate Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 3,611 was on hand to watch the nation's finest keglers compete for $5,000 in prizes.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 13-- The $30,000,000 Cross County Center in Yonkers, one of the largest suburban shopping areas developed in the last few years, is receiving only 18 per cent of its business from persons who formerly patronized stores in downtown Yonkers.

WITH the optimism of an oil company expecting to bring in two new wells at one digging, the Metropolitan Opera gambled on a new dramatic soprano and a new dramatic tenor in the leading roles of "Aida" last night.
VIENNA, Nov. 13--Diplomatic and Red Cross motor convoys from Vienna were delayed and failed to reach Budapest today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)-- The executive secretary of the American Association of LandGrant Colleges and State Universities cautioned today against what he called "disturbing" proposals for Federal scholarships.

More than 300 persons honored the memory of Knute Rockne at the Touchdown Club of New York's "Knute Rockne Memorial Luncheon" at Leone's Restaurant yesterday. The affair marked the twenty-fifth anniversary of the death of the great Notre Dame football coach in a plane crash in 1931.

Clifford Mooers of Walnut Springs, Ky., and Boerne, Tex., one of the best-known men in horse-racing, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in a waiting room at LaGuardia Airport in Queens. His age was 67.
EARL VAN SICKLE has been a gentlemen's tailor for more than sixty years. He started as an apprentice in Indianapolis, his home town, in the Nineties, worked in Cincinnati and St. Louis.

A Census Bureau report making age-group comparisons with 1950 confirms what was well known from other sources, that the many children born after World War II are reaching an age when their parents want them to go to school.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Nov. 13--Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, retiring Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, warned here today that the Soviet Union and the Soviet bloc would be "destroyed" 'if they attacked the West. He said that would be the outcome "as sure as day follows night."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13--A Defense Department advisory committee said today that the department's security classification system was "sound in concept." The House Government Information subcommittee resumed hearings designed to show that it was no such thing.

An offering of $7,605,000 of 3 7/8 per cent Louisville and Nashville Railroad equipment trust certificates, due from 1957 to 1971, is being made by an investment banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. The certificates are priced to yield from 3.75 to 3.90 per cent.
A suggestion for the use of what amounts to advertising techniques in selling was put before the Sales Executives Club at its weekly luncheon at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday.

Restrictions an power pleasure boats were proposed here yesterday before a Congressional committee seeking data on the problems of the nation's boat owners.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 13--American track and field athletes have recovered from numerous ills and aches and are approaching their record-breaking form at the Olympic trials of last June. This was the reassuring word of Coach James Kelly today as his squad put in one of its best work days in preparation for the games of the sixteeenth Olympiad.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 13--The United Nations' failure to act on the eve of Moscow's mass attack on Hungary was back in the spotlight again today as a result of the "regrets" expressed in Paris by Premier Guy Mollet.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13--The Senate majority leader said today he regarded the use of a United Nations police force in Egypt as only "a temporary expedient to prevent the outbreak of large-scale war."

Sales of the nation's chain and mail order concerns scored a 6.9 per cent gain in October compared with volume in the like month of 1955, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times. Sales for the ten months ended Oct. 31 were 9 per cent above the 1955 level.
Antonio Lazo, a retired New York investment banker, died Sunday in Tucson, Ariz., after a long illness, He was 69 years old and formerly resided in Greenwich, Conn.
NORTH HILLS, L.I., Nov. 13 --The Long Island Professional Golfers Association ended its tournament season today with a pro-pro event at the Links Golf Club.

Harrison estate to Mario Gonzalez, owner of the "fee" adjoining at 609-11 Third Avenue. The leased property gives Mr. Gonzalez an "L" around the southeast corner of Third Avenue and Fortieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UP)-- The Interstate Commerce Commission today gave opponents ten extra days, or until Dec. 24, to file objections to a 15 per cent freight rate increase proposed by Eastern and Western railroads.

MIAMI, Nov. 16 (AP)--Florida's wealthiest athlete--a 3year-old race horse named Needles--arrived at Hialeah today to face a welcoming delegation that included the mayor, high school majorettes, a beauty queen and civic and business leaders.
PARIS, Nov. 16--Approximately 200 members of the Parliaments of the fifteen North Atlantic Treaty countries will seek here next week early means of tightening their political and economic links.

An automatic dishwasher that will wash a complete table service for twelve persons has been introduced by General Electric. This new model, the "Empress 30" is one of three new models for 1957. The other two units are the "Princess 24" and a new version of the Mobile Maid.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Nov. 16 (AP)--A Brazilian welterweight, Paulo de Jesus, outpointed an Argentine, Oscar Pita, in ten rounds tonight.

The Great Northern Railway Company reported yesterday for the ten months ended Oct. 31 a 4.8 per cent rise in operating revenues, but a 4.6 per cent decline in net income, compared with figures for the corresponding period of 1955.
PENSACOLA, Fla., Nov. 16 (AP) --A northwest Florida farmer jailed last May for refusing to sign his 1954 cotton crop report was placed on five years' probation today for resisting Federal officers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP)--Henry Kennedy retained his individual title today as he paced Michigan State to the Big Ten crosscountry championship with the best team score in the meet's history, 21 points. It was the Spartans' fifth Big Ten title in six years.
MANILA, Saturday, Nov. 17 (AP)--A large British tanker was reported to have sunk today off the southwest Philippines.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 16 (Reuters)--The West German Government said today it would give every visitor from East Germany a gift of 10 marks (about $2.73) for pocket money.
JAKARTA, Nov. 16 (AP)--The Indonesian Olympic soccer team beat the United States, 7--5, before a capacity crowd of 30,000 in Jakarta Stadium today. The Indonesians led, 4--2, at halftime.

Luther Lassiter of Elizabeth City, N.C., defeated Jimmy Moore of Albuquerque, 150--70, in the national pocket billiards tournament at Judice's Academy in Brooklyn last night. The seven-inning victory was Lassiter's twelfth. He has lost once.

GARDENA, Calif., Nov. 16 (UP) --Billy Maxwell of Odessa, Tex., led the second half of the splitfield qualifying group in the $3,500 Gardena Valley open golf tournament today with a 65, but was one shot behind yesterday's low scorer, Paul O'Leary of Bismark, N.D.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UP) --The State Department, in its foreign service newsletter to United States diplomats abroad, said today it was considering an extra allowance to compensate for the rising "cost of loving." The department hurriedly explained this was a typographical error.
WARSAW, Nov. 16 (AP)--Victims of Stalinist-era police terror in Poland went insane after seven days of interrogation and others feigned lunacy to escape, an official Communist document states.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 16 (AP) --Reports reaching here today said about fifty Arabs were killed and more than twentyfive wounded by Israeli soldiers in food riots Monday near the Gaza Strip.
Amateur and professional astronomers will turn their eyes skyward for a view of the year's only total eclipse of the moon tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) --A Federal Power Commission examiner today recessed indefinitely a hearing on an American Louisiana Pipe Line Company expansion project aimed at increasing consumer supplies of natural gas in Michigan and Wisconsin.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 16--Jesse OWens, the personal representative of President Eisenhower to the Olympic Games, arrived on the scene today after a bumpy flight from Honolulu and scored a characteristic Olympic triumph.

A lively performance of Verdi's "Il Trovatore" last night at the Metropolitan Opera House brought the second appearances here of the two young Italian stars who made their debuts last Tuesday in "Aida."

MONTREAL, Nov. 16 (Canadian Press)--The McColl-Frontenac Oil Company, Ltd., will make an offer to shareholders of Regent Refining (Canada), Ltd., to exchange their shares for McColl stock on the basis of six McColl common shares for nineteen Regent.
HONOLULU, T.H., Nov. 16-- Reaction to the remarks of General O'Daniel today ranged from polite doubt to flat contradiction.
F. Prescott Hammond Jr., an attorney who specialized in corporate and estate law, died yesterday after a brief illness at St. Luke's Hospital. His age was 57.
TRENTON, Nov. 16--Leaders of the Republican-controlled Legislature today reiterated their strong opposition to any increase in New Jersey's 4-centa-gallon tax on gasoline.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) --President Eisenhower's Administration moved today to prepare a new set of amendments to the Taft-Hartley Labor Law for the next session of Congress.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 16 (UP)--Nine persons, including six children, wer killed today by a fireworks explosion. The blast razed three workers' homes in the Barrio Ingles, or English district, of Bogota.
DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 16 (UP) --The University of Dayton announced today that it would present its seventh annual Marianist award to Frank Duff, the Irish founder of the Legion of Mary.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 16 (UP) --About 100 teen-agers, urged on by a 13-year-old girl, battered a traffic patrolman with fists and schoolbooks today and then hurled stones at two police cars called to rescue him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16-- House Democrats disclosed today that they had punished Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat of Manhattan, for his support of President Eisenhower in the recent election.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 16-- Argentina's Provisional Government headed by President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu faced serious trouble on two fronts today.
Two extra dividends of $1 a share each and the quarterly dividend of 56 cents a share on the common stock were declared yesterday by directors of the Miami Copper Company.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UP)-- The Voice of America has postponed plans for Representativeelect D.S. Saund to make recorded broadcasts for transmission to India.
MOSCOW, Nov. 16--The Soviet Union has pulled the props from under its much publicized campaign to enlist "volunteers" to serve in Egypt.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) --The irrational Coal Association today estimated soft coal production for the week ended last Saturday at 10,165,000 tons, compared with 10,585,000 in the preceding week.
Memo for Santa's helpers: be sure to use a lead-free paint when refurbishing toys and children's furniture. Some coatings contain substances that are harmful when swallowed by youngsters.
Excellent with a broiled ham steak are fresh pear halves that have been baked and garnished with pork sausage. Mashed or escalloped potatoes round out this main dish.

SYDNEY, Australia, Saturday, Nov. 17 (AP)--Althea Gibson of New York today added the New South Wales singles title to her French and Italian tennis championships. She beat the American and Wimbledon champion. Shirley Fry of St. Petersburg, Fla., 10--8, 6--2, in the All-American final at the White City courts.
The Rev. William Howard Melish was denounced yesterday by Bishop James P. De Wolfe of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island.

QUONSET POINT, R.I., Nov. 16 (AP)--Divers working in choppy seas 200 yards off the seawall here this afternoon recovered the bodies of three Navy airmen killed in the take-off crash of a carrier plane shortly after 8 A.M. today.
The shipping industry yesterday urged the Federal Maritime Board to call a meeting of shipping management and employes to solve emergency questions brought on by the Suez Canal.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16--The General Assembly voted 45 to 9 today to halt Dec. 23 for a nine-day Christmas recess and reconvene Jan. 2, 1957.

VIENNA, Nov. 16--Hungarian and Western Red Cross delegates agreed tonight on plans that it was hoped would lead to some measure of neutral supervision of relief efforts in the war-shattered satellite nation.
NORWAY, Nov. 16--The Norwegian Government ordered all oil companies today to reduce all deliveries of oil and gasoline by 10 per cent.

John F. (Chick) Meehan, former New York University and Manhattan College football coach, and two other men were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges of conducting an extensive black market operation in steel during the war in Korea.

Harllee Branch Jr., president of the Georgia Power Company, an operating subsidiary of the Southern Company, was named president of the parent company yesterday, succeeding C.B. McManus, who was elected to the new post of vice chairman.
Day or night, when serious illness or accident strikes, people turn for help to their ... nearest hospital, They know that doctors and nurses in the hospital are ready to care for them.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UP)-- Admiral Arleigh A. Burke, Chief of Naval Operations, will receive the highest award of the American Ordnance Association in New York Dec. 5.
"Ding Dong School," the television show for nursery schoolage children, will be dropped by the National Broadcasting Company at the end of the year as part of a weekday morning program shake-up.

ALBANY, Nov. 16 (UP)--Arthur Levitt, State Controller, announced today the distribution of $22,743,419 as per-capita assistance to cities, towns and villages of the state. The payment is the third quarterly installment in the state's 1956-57 fiscal year. New York City's share of the total is $13,249,140.

The Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company of New York has acquired Northern New Jersey Mortgage Associates of Teaneck, N. J. The latter company will operate as a wholly owned subsidiary of the parent company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UP) --The Federal Food and Drug Administration said today there was a continuing menace from Hoxsey cancer medicines despite a new Federal court verdict against them. It said it would seek an injunction to halt further interstate shipments.

When the Cunard liner Franconia sailed late yesterday afternoon from New York, on what may be her last trip before being consigned to the scrap heap, her hold contained the entire scenic effects for the London revue, "Cranks," opening here at the Bijou Theatre on Nov. 26.
An address this week by President Tito of Yugoslavia appears to be a declaration of political war against the Stalinist leaders in the Soviet and European Communist parties.

YONKERS, Nov. 16 (UP)-- Torrid, owned by the Sherwood Farm of Irvington, N.J., and driven by John Simpson, slipped through along the rail to defeat the odds-on favorite, Adios Harry, in tonight's Grandview Pace before 21,106 fans at Yonkers Raceway.

MANILA, Saturday, Nov. 17 (UP)--Little Cezar retained the Filipino bantamweight title, by fighting to a draw last night with Danny Kidd. There were no knockdowns, but both fighters slugged it out in the closing rounds in knockout attempts. About 8,000 saw the match.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16--Grain futures were weak in the absence of aggressive buying support today on the Board of Trade. There was some local selling on the longshoremen's strike at Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico ports and some profit taking by longs.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 16-- Mayor Joseph M. Healey or Kearny was elected president of the New Jersey State League of Municipalities today.

ALAMOGORDO, N.M., Nov. 16 (AP)--The glow of the night sky is not totally dependent on lunar influence, the Air Force said today. Rocket experiments conducted by scientists at Hollman Air Development Center, Show that the glow is due to photochemical processes in the upper air.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 16--The Danish Parliament decided today to introduce the immediate rationing of fuel oil to cut the country's consumption by 20 per cent.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 16--Maj. Gen. E.L.N. Burns, commander of the United Nations Emergency Force now landing in Egypt, appeared today to be preparing for a long pull in the Middle East.
ATHENS, Nov. 16 (Reuters) --Constantine Karamanlis, Premier of Greece, will meet with President Tito of Yugoslavia during a visit to Belgrade next month, it was announced here today.

The seventy-ninth meeting between Yale and Princeton commands top attention on today's college football program. With the Ivy League title hanging in the balance, the Bulldogs and the Tigers will have at it before a capacity crowd of 68,000 in the Bowl at New Haven.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP)-- The Canadian Pacific Railway Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to acquire exclusive control of the Spokane International Railroad, an important link between the Pacific northwest and southwest Canadian provinces.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 16 (AP)--The working committee of the Pakistan Moslem League, main Opposition party, called today on the Pakistan Government to leave the Commonwealth.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP)-- The Maritime Administration said today that forty-four bidders had submitted more than 200 offers for the purchase of six T-2 tankers that the Government proposed to sell.
This week was short but busy for sugar dealers, with heavy volume and sharp price rises.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 16 (UP)--A committee of the International Association of Fire Chiefs organized today to work out minimum standards for fire fighting equipment throughout the country.

PARIS, Nov. 16 (Reuters)-- Guy Mollet, Premier of France, appealed today to all Frenchmen to observe next Sunday as a day of mourning for "the martyrdom of Hungary, of shattered Hungary which refused slavery."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16-- Averege wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.2 per cent during the week ended Tuesday to 115.6 per cent of their 1947-49 level, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
The Transport Workers Union began yesterday to rebuild its fences on the city transit system.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 16 (AP)--A Federal grand jury will convene here Nov. 27 to conduct "a full-scale investigation" of the alleged payment of $35,000 by a Missouri utility to Orville Hodge when he was state auditor.

The Cantata Singers revived a pleasant custom last night at Town Hall: they celebrated St. Cecilia's Day. Perforce, though, they did it six days early, since the actual day of the patron saint of music is Nov. 22, and this year that date is pre-empted by a celebration with a much shorter history, the American Thanksgiving.

MIAMI, Nov. 16 (UP)--Miami's Hurricanes, frustrated in their own bowl hopes by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, savagely riddled Clemson, 21--0, before 47,603 fans tonight in the same stadium where the Tigers hope to return New Year's Day.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16--Latvians are hoarding scarce commodities such as soap, matches and salt in fear of another world war. A report to this effect was printed yesterday in Soviet Latvia, newspaper of the Central Commitee of the Latvian Communist party. Another war is not coming, the paper told its readers.

The Chamber Music Workshop of the Society for Strings will open its fourth season of weekly sessions tomorrow evening from 8 to 10 o'clock. Registration will take place at 5 P.M. tomorrow on the fourth floor of 130 West Fifty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16-- Senator Price Daniel, Democrat of Texas, said today that phone calls and correspondence reaching his office were 10-to-1 in favor of his stand on when to resign from the Senate to become Governor of Texas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16-- The Navy said tonight that trouble with its second atomic submarine was limited to the sodium cooling system of the atomic plant. It denied that there was trouble in the Seawolf's atomic reactor.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 16-- Accidents, atoms and age have emerged as major new public health problems.
LONDON, Nov. 16--Aubrey Jones, Minister of Fuel and Power, cautioned industry today against any over-optimistic views on fuel supplies.

DENVER, Nov. 16 (AP)--Ice in the fuel lines was termed today the cause of a power failure that forced a B-36 intercontinental bomber to crash-land in a field yesterday. Two of the twentyone men aboard were critically injured.
Since no Communist gains have been made over water, this country holds a preponderant advantage, as long as the seas are free, Thomas S. Gates Jr., Under Secretary of the Navy, said last night.
AMITYVILLE, L.I., Nov. 16 --Game-time tomorrow can't come soon enough for the football-happy residents of this town.

ALBANY, Nov. 16--If we have learned nothing else from the ugly Middle Eastern crisis, surely we recognize the need to re-examine and, where possible, improve our structure of alliances. These must be strengthened politically, economically and militarily.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 16 (Reuters)--Seventeen British soldiers were wounded by an explosion at a British military camp in the Paphos district of western Cyprus tonight. Seven of the soldiers were seriously injured.
Strength at the opening failed to last in yesterday's stock market. Gains were steadily nibbled away and by the close The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks showed no change on the day.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 16 (AP) --Queen Mother Esmet Molouk Pahlevi of Iran suffered a fracture leg in a truck-car wreck last night. The mother of Mohammed Riza Shah Pahlevi was en route to Mardabad, about twenty-five miles west of Teheran, when a truck hit her car.
MOSCOW, Nov. 16--Polish and Soviet Communist party and Government leaders continued today their discussion of mutual problems including economic and political relations.

OMAHA, Nov. 16 (AP)--Final unofficial returns from Nebraska's Third Congressional district showed today that Representative R.D. Harrison, a Republican, apparently had scored a mail-vote triumph over Lawrence Brock, a Democrat.

HYDERABAD, India, Nov. 16 (Reuters)--The Indian Socialist party urged India today to withdraw from the Commonwealth and to sever diplomatic relations with Britain and France and boycott their goods until they withdrew from Egypt.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 16 (AP)-- Frank Robinson, a Cincinnati Redlegs' outfielder, will become a college student Monday. Robinson, 21, the National League rookie-of-the-year for 1956, has entered Xavier University here and will attend classes until it is time for him to report for spring training.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 16.--(AP)-- Two major air passenger carriers to Miami face threatened strikes before the winter season tourist rush begins.

PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., Nov. 16 (AP)--A marine court-martial sentenced today a former junior drill instructor to one year at hard labor and a bad conduct discharge on four counts of cruelty to recruits. The sentence is subject to review.
TORONTO, Nov. 16 (Canadian Press)--Ireland tonight wrested the championship from Mexico in the individual jumping events at the Royal Winter Fair horse show.
STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 16 --Henry Schenck, former Connecticut State Budget Director, died here today in his home, 2085 Bedford Street. His age was 78.
The Navy tanker Shawnee Trail, escorted by the Coast Guard cutter Half Moon, was proceeding at reduced speed toward Bermuda late yesterday with a dangerous crack in her deck and hull.

United States consumption of newsprint in October was slightly rower than in the corresponding month last year, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday. Consumption and production totals for the year so far, however, continued to rise to record levels.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 16--The Amateur Athletic Union of the United States today accepted Russia's invitation to compete in a "super" track meet in Moscow next year. It also asked Congress to clear the way for a return visit by a Russian team in 1958.

VIENNA, Nov. 16--Charges that Hungarian Jews were persecuted and killed by revolutionary groups in the last three weeks were dismissed here today as "complete fabrications" by the European director of the American Jewish Committee.
Cotton futures closed 4 points up to 12 points off in rather light trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Only the nearby December rose.

The Black Decker Manufacturing Company, which makes portable electric tools, in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 attained the highest soles and earnings in its forty-six-year history, Robert D. Black, president and board chairman, reported yesterday.
Sophocles' "Oedipus Rex" will open at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse on Jan. 7. Motion Picture Distributors, Inc., is the distributor.

Test borings are under way in Washington Square for the foundation of a new New York University student center.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 16 (AP)-- Clarence W. Miles, former club president, resigned today from the board of directors of the Baltimore Orioles. A stockholders' meeting resulted in the naming of all other board members to another term and in the re-election of James Keelty as president.

An 18-year-old girl and a 16year-old boy who had caused disturbances while picketing the Soviet United Nations headquarters building at 680 Park Avenue were paroled yesterday in the custody of the Youth Counsel Bureau in Adolescent Court.

The unusual amount of moisture that New Yorkers noticed yesterday morning on roads, walls, windows and windshields was attributed by the Weather Bureau to extraordinarly high dew points.

Our Brooklyn Dodgers have now completed their exhibition tour of Japan. They won fourteen games, lost four and tied one. On several occasions an outspoken Japanese press declared that they were something less than overwhelmingly impressive. They were tired and showed it.

BOYNTON BEACH, Fla., Nov. 25 (Ap)--Harry C. Black, chairman of the board of the A. S. Abel Company, publisher of the Baltimore Sunpapers, died unexpectedly at his winter home here today. He was 69 years old.

IT was bitterly cold at the Yankee stadium yesterday but the Giants and the Bears put on so spectacular a show that pulses pounded in heart-warming fashion. Not many folks in a crowd of 55,191 even noticed that the temperatures on the outside were hovering near the freezing point.
Construction of Luna Park Houses on the site of the former amusement park at Coney Island will start early next year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25-The United States vote in the United Nations last night--with the Asian-African bloc against Britain and France--struck many foreign diplomats here as a step toward something new in American foreign policy.
BOSTON, Nov. 25 (U P)--Johnny Peirson scored two second-period goals to spark the league-leading Boston Bruins to a 3-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight.

Bills intended to deprive Park Commissioner Robert Moses of unrestricted power to let concessions and grant permits in city parks will be introduced in the City Council to morrow. Two measures drafted by the Citizens Union will be offered by Councilman Stanley M, Isaacs, Manhattan Republican-Liberal.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25--The three-man board of inquiry created this week by President Eisenhower in the dock strike ran into its first obstacle almost immediately: news photographers.
THAT conviction of our grandmothers that the culinary preparations for Christmas must begin far in advance is not entirely dead, we are glad to note. From Lutherville, Md., Mrs. Louis Adezio writes:

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 25 --If local governments throughout the nation are to catch up with needed public works construction by 1961. They will have to spend $20,100,000,000 a year, or about twice as much as they are now spending, a convention of investment bankers was told here today.

LEHMAN ENGEL is a brave man to let his new opera, "The Soldier," have its premiere in a concert version at Carnegie Hall. This is a work that cries out for the illusion that staging would impart, and one would guess that it would be most effec-- tive in a small theatre.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 25--This city's bid to return to a position it held a century ago as a busy world port has collapsed, with no immediate prospect of revival.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 25--The steel industry is running into some minor breakdowns due to "pushing" equipment excessively for many months. This mean that carryovers--broken shipping promises--into 1957 will be substantial on many steel products. Efforts to cut these down have been partially successful on flat rolled-steel items, but not on plates and shapes.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold took action today to implement General Assembly resolutions calling for evacuation of foreign troops from Egypt and the clearance of the Suez Canal.
College football's last Saturday of general activity failed to produce any major disturbances among the nation's leading teams. There were some surprises, but no shockers.

A SUBWAY token is a New Yorker's passport this year to the Rue St. Honore in Paris, the Via Condotti in Rome or the Kaernterstrasse in Vienna. Imported gifts for the home seem to outnumber domestic items and, happily enough prices are not seriously affected by trans-Atlantic shipment.
Hakoah scored its seventh victory in eight American League soccer games yesterday by downing the Brooklyn Italians, 2-1, at Zerega Oval, the Bronx.
WARSAW, Nov. 25--The Polish Communist party cautiously aligned itself today with President Tito of Yugoslavia against Stalinist leaders within the Soviet and other European parties.
The Rangers gained a tie with the Canadiens at Madison Square Garden last night.
To the 55,191 fans at Yankee stadium yesterday, one play stood out. It was spectacular. It lifted the spirits of the Chicago Bears and started them toward a 17-17 tie with the New York Giants.

The ten-day temporary injunction signed by Judge Bryan on Saturday has, suspended the Atlantic Coast dock strike until at least Dec. 4. The injunction will probably be continued, after a formal hearing next Friday, for another seventy days--
MADRID, Nov. 25 (Reuters) --Generalissimo Francisco Franco's plans for Spain's future form of government are beginning to take more precise shape.
"I'd like a good whisky, a bourbon, not too strong, not too expensive, but with a good flavor," said the customer to the clerk in the package store.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 25-- The Egyptian operations have strengthened Britain's determination to hold Cyprus.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP)--Ollie Matron scored twice, including a 79-yard touchdown run, to fire up the Chicago Cardinals for a 38-27 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers on snow-encrusted Comiskey Park today.
Dr. Martin Dodge, of 277 Park Avenue, First Deputy Commissioner of Commerce of New York, died yesterday after a cerebral hemorrhage while visiting friends in Millburn, N. J. He was 64 years old.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Monday, Nov. 26 (UP)--The assault on the record books continued today as the Olympic Games competition entered its fifth day.

Worthington--(Tony) Miner has resigned as executive producer of the "Kaiser Aluminum Hour," a drama series televised on alternate Tuesdays from 9:30 to 10:30 P. M. by the National Broadcasting Company.

Clarence G. Michalis, president of the Savings Bank Association of the State of New York, will assure George A. Mooney, State Superintendent of Banks, today that Empire State Savings banks have no present intention of converting to national institutions.
The Russian Orthodox Church is opposed to "aggression" in the Middle East and is participating with the Soviet Government in sending "material aid" to "those who suffer in Hungary."
Wilmette, Ill., is planning to offer $2,275,000 of water revenue bonds on Dec. 11. The obligations will be dated Dec. 1, 1956, and will come due on Jan. 1 from 1958 to 1996.
LONDON, Nov, 25--Hugh Gaitskell, Labor party leader, said today that in the Middle East Britain had become a grave political liability to the West.
PORT SAID, Egypt, Nov. 25-- Maj. Gen. E. L. M. Burns of Canada, commander of the United nations Emergency Force, conferred here today with the commanders of the BritishFrench expedition in Egypt.
The American Cancer Society issued a carefully qualified report yesterday that available evidence indicated cigarette smoking was a hazard to health.

Plans are going ahead for a large office building on the site of Carnegie Hall. This was announced yesterday by Louis J. Glickman, head of the Glickman Corporation, the realty concern that bought Carnegie Hall last July.

CAMP KILMER, N. J., Nov. 25 --It has become much easier to process Hungarian refugees here than to clear thousands of queries about them that pour in by telephone and mail from all over the United States.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UP) --The Securities and Exchange Commission today issued a ten point guide to help the public guard against being gypped by "unscrupulous stock operators."

The Soviet-Yugoslav controversy begun by Tito's speech at--Pula two weeks ago provides an object case of the Soviet leaders using Stalinist tactics to mislead and deceive Soviet public opinion. Any notion that there is even a glimmering of honesty or sincerity in the Soviet leaders' behavior must be dispelled by the vivid example of distortion this case represents.
Unions representing a virtually complete cross-section of airline labor have moved to give themselves a single voice before Congress.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov.25-- Francis McCullagh, author, war correspondent, linguist and soldier, died here today of a cerebral hemorrhage at New York Hospital, Westchester Division. His age was 82.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 25 --Two young men and a Himalayan prince arrived in New Delhi today. The prince was met with a salute of fifteen cannon and the two young men were met with incense and adoration.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 25 --The theft of $274,000 in cash from the 1,000-acre estate of a former Solicitor General of the United States was reported to the police today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov, 25The tension between Iraq and Syria is near the breaking point. The Iraqis are alarmed by reports of rapidly growing Soviet influence in Syria. They are angry at syrian propaganda directed against them and Syrian efforts to stir up trouble inside Iraq.
A gift of $500,000 toward founding a medical library has been received by the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

TELEVISION Provided a delightful spree last night-- an impeccable production of George Bernard Shaw's "Man and Superman." Maurice Evans was the helpless victim and Joan Greenwood the irresistible life force. For TV this season it was heady wine indeed--fun and substance in one sparkling package.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 25--The stock market last week suffered from almost continued selling pressure under the lead of Royal Dutch and Unilever.

BALTIMORE, Nov, 25 (AP)-- Eight B-52 jet Planes completed record nonstop flights of up to 17,OOO miles today, proving the United States Air Force's ability to deliver nuclear bombs to any point on the globe.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Nov. ?5 -Iceland has agreed to let United States troops remain in control of the strategic Keflavik Air Base--at a price.
Fifty-nine employes in the city's public schools were directed during the last year to answer questions concerning membership in the Communist party.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25-- President Eisenhower packed his bags today for a golfing vacation at Augusta, Ga.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 25 --Gold Coin, a handsome chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. John J. Farrell of Darien, Conn., carried off two titles as the Boulder Brook Club's fall horse show ended tonight.

Probably the Greeks pact words for it," Adam Adam, coach of Riverdale School's soccer team, said with a grin the other day. "But I can't find them. I've searched for the proper words in Greek as well as in at least four, other languages."

The fundamental principles of American military strategy have again been brought to public attention by the latest war scare. The question raised was brutally simple. If Moscow decided to fly formations of armed "volunteers" into the Middle East, how should we react?

The United States found itself in strange companionship last Saturday at the United Nations, when it voted with such U. N. members as Byelorussia, the Ukraine, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics anda tragic, terrible and misleading appellation today--Hungary against the United Kingdom and France.
The May Department Stores Company is planning a public offering of $25,000,000 of general mortgage bonds. Most of the money raised would be used in connection with May Depart

Francis Raymond Stark, retired vice president and general counsel of the Western Union Telegraph Company, died yesterday at his home, 514 West End Avenue. He was 79 years old and had been ill for about a year.

Sales of used carpet are booming all over the country, according to Gerald C. Denebrink, sales vice president of C. H. Masland Sons, a large manufacturer of carpeting with mills located in Carlysle, Pa.
MOSCOW, Nov. 25--The Soviet Union's treatment of Imre Nagy, former Hungarian Premier, threatens a serious breach in the Kremlin's relations with Yugoslavia, in the opinion of some observers here.

LONDON, Nov. 25--The Soviet Union's rapid ascendancy as a major naval power is the most significant development in Soviet grand strategy since World War II, according to the 1956-57 edition of Jane's Fighting Ships.

BONN, Germany, Nov, 25-- The pivotal Free Democratic party, largest of West Germany's constellation of minority political groups, is reappraising its principles and political tactics. The outcome of the intraparty struggle may be of major significance for Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's bid next year for another four years in office.

The question of who has the power to choose the next Attorney General of New York State promises to be a lively year-end issue. Various collateral questions complicate the matter posed by election of Jacob K. Javits, Republican, to the United States Senate. Does the con

BALTIMORE, Nov. 25 (AP)--A kickoff return of 103 yards by Halfback Tom Wilson of the Los Angeles Rams was lost in the shuffle today as the Baltimore Colts hit their highest total in the National Football League in routing the Rams, 56-21.

DR. FREDERICK M. ECKER, chairman of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's board of directors and head of the annual Christmas Seals les carmpaign now under way, was one of the first telephone users in this city.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 25--A move for a Presidential investigation of fire insurance rating systems was pressed today by the Mayors of United States cities.
The New York Times Youth Forum addressed itself yesterday to a topic close to home: "What Makes Teen-agers Tick?"

CLEVELAND, Nov. 25 (AP)-- A 26-yard touchdown pays from Eddie Le Baron to Johnny Carson with a minute and a half to go gave the Washington Redskins a 20-17 victory over the Cleveland, Browns in a National Football League game today.
PARIS, Nov. 25--A prolonged obstruction of the Suez Canal and persistent troubles in the Middle East would seriously affect France's foreign trade, aside from the problem of oil supplies.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Monday, Nov. 26 (AP)--Ray Perez, a Hawaiian flyweight, gained a quarter-final berth for the United States today when he whipped Frantisok Majdloch of Czechoslovakia.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 (AP) --The San Francisco FortyNiners and the Philadelphia Eagles each kicked a field goal, scored a touchdown and made a goal line stand at their 1 as the teams played to a 10-10 tie before 19,326 fans at Connie Mack Stadium today.

Led by coal, grain and scrap, the steamship charter market last Week continued its steady , climb. Rates advanced in virtually all commodities and the over-all dry-cargo freight-rate index moved upward for the tenth consecutive week.
The resignation of Hospital Commissioner Basil C. MacLean, effective next Feb. 1, was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

The rationing queue, a familiar feature of the British scene during World War II and the early post-war years, was back, temporarily at least, in that country last week. With the rationing of gasoline scheduled to go into effect in Britain on Dec. 17 as a consequence of the Suez

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25-- Abba Eban, Israel's Ambassador to the United States, charged today that United Nations actions would result in strengthening President Gamel Abdel Nasser of Egypt as a threat to peace in the Middle East.
Municipal Court Justice Carson deWitt Baker has sent Mayor Wagner his resignation, effective immediately.
McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Monday, Nov. 26--An Air Force sergeant from St. Louis plateau yesterday. The jump, in 17-degrees-below-zero cold, was the first such feat in Antarctic history.

The fourth annual Great American Mountain Rally ended here yesterday in a bit of confusion. After all the prizes had been presented a message from the factory of one of the con testants asked for a recheck of the scores.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov, 25-- One of the earth's closest neighbors, a recently discovered small planet, has been given a name.

More than 4,000 longshoremen were back at their jobs in New York Harbor yesterday. Other thousands worked on piers from Maine to Texas as East and Gulf Coast ports prepared to resume normal activity today after nine days of strike idleness.
A full-time state staff to help local leaders fight "increasingly rigid patterns of residential segregation" was advocated yesterday by a unit of the State Commission Against Discrimination.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 25--The Russian squad, the largest representing any country at the sixteenth Olympiad, is not doing well, though it has been training harder and been subject to much more exacting discipline than any other team here.
A Roman Catholic archdiocesan official yesterday called Nikita S. Khrushchev one of "the false prophets" against whom Christ warned nearly two thousand years ago.
ROME, Nov. 25--The Italian Communist party proclaimed today that the downgrading of Stalin was a one-way road on which there was no turning back.
Foreign Minister Mahmoud Fawzi of Egypt said yesterday that what the Egyptians did with the Suez Canal "is our own business."

LITTLE AMERICA V, Antarctica, Nov, 23--Admiral George J. Dufek, commander of the United States expedition in Antarctica, said tonight that it should become clear within the next ten days whether the trail party seeking a route through the coastal crevasses of Marie Byrd Land had been successful.
A Kentuckian who has spent more than half his life in Japan, where he founded and now directs a "model Christian community," asked a New York congregation yesterday for funds to continue his work.
ZURICH, Now. 25--A longtime trader on the Zurich Stock Exchange described business last week as the worst he could remember.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Nov. 26--Christianity in the Far East is hampered by a "new wave of divisiveness" and by a mass resurgence of Buddhism, some 300 foreign mission executives of forty-five denominations were told here tonight.

A stately evergreen, 335 miles from its home grounds, spread its branches yesterday over Rockefeller Plaza--ready to be dressed with lights and ornaments for the holidays. It is a white spruce, standing sixtyfour feet, with a cluster of cones on its crown.
In a report to the Board of Estimate yesterday the City Planning Commission was cool to extensive changes in the 1957 capital budget proposed last week by Budget Director Abraham D. Beame.
About 65 per cent of this nation's natural rubber supply came from the Far East by way of the Suez Canal before that artery was blocked.

The Russian mass slaughter of Hungarian workers is already sapping Communist strength in the European labor unions on this side of the Iron Curtain. For example, recent news from France shows a widening of a split there that has been evident to close observers for some time past.

A 12-year-old pianist, Lorin Hollander, was the center of curiosity at the third concert of the Little Orchestra Society's season last night in Town Hall. He replaced Nicole Henriot, who underwent an emergency operation last week in Paris.

THE best love affair in any of Mary Mc-- Carthy's books is her own, with Venice. There are many reservations' among her observations in "Venice Observed," but it is to her "the world's loveliest city," the town of "generation after generation of incomparable artists," the place where nothing ever happens but adventures.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 26-- The old warning "let the buyer beware" is still the investor's best friend, a spokesman for the Securities and Exchange Commission admitted here today.
John Houseman, producer and director of stage plays and motion pictures for more than twenty years, has signed a television contract with the Columbia Broadcasting System.
VIENNA, Nov. 26--The United States Consulate here will begin tomorrow a painstaking search for refugees being sought by relatives in the United States.

Delegates from twenty-eight states representing seventeen national Jewish organizations met here last night and heard speakers report on the global issues resulting from the tension in the Middle East.

IT is distressing when a vital young painter aligns him self with a past that can never be his. Such is the case with Harry Jackson, whose defection from the abstract school of painting has been cheered by traditionalists and lamented...
FOUR agreeable young actors have come a long way with a light cargo. They constitute the entire cast of a miniature London revue, "Cranks," which opened at the Bijou last evening.
The Consolidated Edison Company notified Mayor Wagner yesterday that it was willing to make an offer for the city's three rapid transit power plants.
ROME. Nov. 26--More frequent consultations on political, economic and cultural matters among all members of the Atlantic pact have been proposed by a committee of the alliance.
Stanley M. Isaacs, Minority Leader of the City Council, said last night that he would move to bar secrecy in the forthcoming debate on whether to expel Councilman Hugh Quinn, Queens Democrat.
PORT SAID, Egypt, Nov. 26-- The evacuation of homeless orphaned and frightened Europeans and Egyptians was under way from Port Said today.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 26-- Soviet frontier guards refused last night to permit a British military train to cross Communist East Germany. The regular West Berlin express to Hannover was turned back at the Marienborn border checkpoint on the ground that its documentation was not in order.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 (AP) --The Green Bay Packers selected Notre Dame quarterback Paul Hornung as their National, Football League bonus choice today after coach Lisle Blackbourn drew the lucky slip from the hat at the pro football draft meeting.

NEW YORK stores have as great a variety of fashion accessory gifts as there are women to receive them. They range from the frivolous to the useful, from the little gift to the very fancy--a big, wide, wonderful selection of presents to delight every woman.
The Philharmonic-Symphony concerts that the late Guido Cantelli was scheduled to have directed from Thursday to Dec. 23 will be led by Dimitri Mitropoulos, Paul Paray and Leonard Bernstein.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26-- Two Southern educators and a Southern editor said today that desegregation by law was bound to succeed in the South. They spoke before the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.
Stocks returned yesterday at the pattern of morning strength, and afternoon sell-off that ruled most of last week.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, Nov. 27 (UP)--The United States added to its point total in the Olympic Games competition today.

MOSCOW, Nov. 26--Premier Chivu Stoica of Rumania arrived here today and promptly pledged his Government to stand with the Soviet Union against all efforts to destroy the "solidarity" of the Communist bloc.
Cocoa, wool and world sugar futures soared yesterday in heavy trading on the New York exchanges. Cocoa rose the 1-centa-pound daily limit in the heaviest volume since Dec. 8, 1941.
The breaking up of a home can be so devastating to a small child that he may be permanently damaged emotionally, a psychiatrist warned yesterday.

TEHERAN, Nov. 26--The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) is reported near agreement with the Iranian Government on a $75,000,000 loan of a type never before granted by that bank.

AUTO PRODUCTION CONTINUES TO LAG DETROIT, Nov. 26 (AP)--The nation's auto makers still are striving for assembly line volume on 1957 model car production. Unless they put on a tremendous burst of speed in December the calendar year's total output will not exceed 5,900,000 units.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 26--The United States basketball team breezed to its third straight victory in the Olympics competition tonight and reached the semi-final round.

An Atomic Energy Commission official warned last night that the United States had "not too much time" to develop atomic energy to meet rising needs for electricity and dwindling supplies of gas, oil and coal.

Loomis J. Grossman, investor, has completed a sale and leaseback transaction involving the seven-story store and office building at 325 Lafayette Street. The structure was purchased from the Beaumont Factors Corporation, which took a longterm lease on the property.

Economics triumphed last night over principle and one of the nation's last notable male sanctuaries was overrun by women. White oak tables in the dark-paneled grill of The Lambs, at 128 West Fortyfourth Street, were shrouded in table cloths as women extended universal suffrage to the right to dinner there any week-night.

The Southern Pacific Company and its separately operated but solely controlled affiliates cleared $5,403,236 last month on total operating revenues of $61,412,160. This compares with $3,897,991 earned in October 1955, when operating revenues were $57,017,096.
Operations of the KimberlyClark Corporation for the six months ended Oct. 31 resulted in a net income of $11,174,501, according to the interim report issued yesterday by John R. Kimberly, president.

An all-star team with a fast, 183-pound backfield operating behind a hard-charging, 191pound line was named yesterday by the coaches of the Catholic High School Football League of the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--The Government's short-term borrowing costs went up again today. The Treasury announced the award of $1,600,005,000 in ninety one-day Treasury bills at an average price of 99.198 equivalent to an annual interest rate of 3.174 per cent

ON Friday, patriotic Scots everywhere will celebrate the Feast of St. Andrew, the Apostle who is Scotland's patron saint. For the St. Andrews Society of New York the date will also mark the 200th anniversary of its founding. The occasion will be observed with a banquet as typically Scotch as a poem by Robert Burns.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 26--President Eisenhower's special assistant for public works told the nation's mayors today that $200,000,000,000 in new construction was needed to bring state and municipal public facilities up to date.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 26--The first world recordbreaking performance in track and field and the almost phenomenal achievements of Tom Courtney and Bob Richards made the competition in the Olympic Games an unforgettable experience for 100,000 onlookers today.

AUGUSTA, Nov. 26--President, Eisenhower finally flew to Augusta today for the vacation he had been planning since he was re-elected Nov. 6 in a landslide. Tensions in ... Europe and the Middle East eased sufficently so the President felt he could leave his White House desk. Augusta

"The Last Station," the first drama written by Erich Maria Remarque, the novelist, who gained international recognition with his World War I novel "All Quiet on the Western Front," is to be done on Broadway next season.

After first telling the Federal Bureau of Investigation his life "wouldn't be worth 3 cents" if he talked, Domenico Bando later gave an incriminating statement of his participation in the plot to blind Victor Riesel, labor columnist, with acid.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 26 --Screen Gems has added another film series to its growing schedule. The project, titled "Western Ranch Party," is a departure from the normal pattern of comedies, adventures and dramas.

Mrs. Elizabeth Stillman Williams, wife of Langbourne M. Williams, president of the Freeport Sulphur Company, died yesterday in her home at 71 East Seventy-first Street. Her age was 51. Mrs. Williams had been active in welfare work in this city and was a former president of the Junior League.

Lou Little's successor at Columbia will be named in late December or early January, a university spokesman said yesterday.

The French are planning a demonstration tour of North America this spring with their twin-jet Caravelle airliner.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26--The Monday session on the Chicago Board of Trade was featured by individuality of action on the part of December wheat. The delivery moved well into new high seasonal ground, maintaining nearly 2 cents of its outside recovery up...
RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 26-- The impression is growing rapidly in diplomatic circles here that United States policy toward North Africa has begun to change.

Georgia-Pacific Corporation yesterday was restrained from further sales of its common stock. The New York Regional Office of the Securities and Exchange Commission obtained a temporary injunction from the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York alleging violations of Sections 5 and 17 of the Securities Act of 1933.

Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks warned yesterday of a rollback in this country's program for expansion of foreign trade. This would occur, he said unless policies of "moderation" prevail on issues of tariffs and import competition.

WARSAW, Nov. 26--The Polish Government granted permission today for Tygodnik Powszechny to resume publication as an independent Roman Catholic newspaper. The well known Craow weekly was suspended in March, 1953, at the height of the struggle betwen the church and the state.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 26 (AP)--Walter McNew, from the University of Texas, put on a blazing finish to win the eighteenth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association crosscountry run in 19:55.7 today.
SINCE they took control in 1951, the Chinese Commu nists have not had an easy time in the remote theocracy of Tibet.

In Iceland the Government of Premier Jonasson has reconsidered its previous insistence on ousting American troops and consented to their continued stay as the only available defense of this key bastion of Western defense.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--The Government reported today that average consumer prices set a record in October for the fourth time in five months. The outlook is for further increases. The Consumer Price Index rose from 117.1 in midSeptember to 117.7 in midOctober. This is a rise of 0.6 points or 0.5 per cent. The base of the index, 100, represents the 1947-49 price average.
Italo Scortichini of Italy took a split decision over Hardy Smallwood of Brooklyn in the ten-round main bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

The Most Rev. Thomas E. Molloy, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn died last night at his Brooklyn residence, 241 Clinton Avenue He had suffered a stroke and an attack of pneumonia on Nov 15. His age was 71. He held the personal title of Archbishop.

VIENNA, Nov. 26--Hungarian workers, especially in Budapest, showed a tendency to return to their jobs today. They acted in accordance with yesterday's decision by the Budapest Workers Council to call for a twentyfour-hour resumption of work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP)-- An official of the Veterans Administration told a House committee today that the agency opposed an increase in the 4 per cent interest rate on veterans' housing loans at the present.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 26--The Yugoslav Communist party warned the Soviet Union tonight that there was only one alternative to granting full equality and independence to the captive countries of Eastern Europe: a return to the brutal methods of Stalin's time.

WASHINGTON, Nov: 26-- The expected resistance began to develop today against moves to give the Democratic party a more liberal look.

POULTNEY, Vt., Nov. 26-- Miss Edith Fahnestock, professor emeritus of Spanish at Vassar College, where she had taught for thirty-one years, died here last Wednesday at a nursing home. She was 84 years old and had lived in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., until last spring.
CAIRO, Nov. 26--British and French nationals have been permitted to leave Egypt "at their own discretion" to save them from the wrath of the people, a Government spokesman said tonight.
A group of scholars, artists, writers, poets and others in the Western Hemisphere protested Russian aggression in Hungary yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26-- The Securities and Exchange Commission received a recommendation today from one of its divisions that it deny permission to the Murchison Brothers of Texas to purchase additional stock in a billion-dollar investment company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26-- Verner W. Clapp, president of the Council on Library Resources, started today a search for a missing chapter in the history of World War II--all the Nazi literature saved for research.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26--Iraq asked the United States today to step up arms deliveries.

Selwyn Lloyd, British Foreign Secretary, said last night that the existence of acute dissension, between the United States and Britain over policy in the Middle East should not be taken "too tragically."

"CAN DO," which had its debut last night on Chan nel 4, is a contest show out of "Beat the Clock" by "The $64,000 Question." Studio participants try to run up a jackpot by guessing whether or not a celebrity can perform a given stunt. With stars, prizes, participation gimmicks and an isolation booth, it is potboiling video, circa 1956.
